Really love this phone. I used to have 2 phones, one for Myanmar and one for US. Now with 2 Sims card, I can enjoy 2 in one. The phone is really light, amazing battery life. I use ATT Sim card for US with no issues.

I only use a smart phone for phone and some message texting. I have no need for all Google apps. However, I have heard raving reviews about the P30 Pro's picture and video taking ability. I travel quite a bit, mostly overseas. Carrying even a small camera is a bit bulky. Also, when I go to concerts or jazz clubs at night, the camera's night photo/video taking capability is less than an iPhone. So, I bought this P30 Pro, highly recommended in reviews and by some of my friends. I have used it and it certainly performs to its acclaims and exceeds my expectations. I can carry it around in my pocket, very convenient. The triple lens can get a 3 dimensional image, incredibly sharp with depth. I have yet to try out the zoom feature. It is also rated high.

I was seriously considering the new i-phone but was really reluctant to pay a huge premium for a brand name and no memory expansion. It was with some reluctance that I ordered this P30-Pro. Having received and used it, I know I made the right choice.
I am running on T-Mobile. My area does not have the new bands so performance is essentially the same as on my old i-phone. Battery life is night and day. Even when new, my old phone struggled to make it through a full 24 hours. This thing just keeps going for 4 days.
Calls and audio work great. I disabled some of the Huwai features, interface is clean and easy to use. All of the apps are available in Play store and work great.
While I can not compare to the latest generation i-phone, I am really impressed with the camera. The zoom is an engineering marvel and night mode is stunning.
On a down note, It does use proprietary memory cards but, the good news is that those are available. I did order and install one, all good although more expensive than a standard memory card.
Only about a week into it but so far it is excellent. Will update if anything changes,

I purchased this simply for the cameras and to that I am in love. As a phone though, it is a limited yet vanilla experience.
Chipset wise you will be hard pressed to find a faster Android on the market. It is blazingly fast and seems to retain it's speed overtime. Also to mention is the battery life which is somewhere between amazing and epic. The fast charging will put enough juice in the device in 30 mins to keep it powered for a day or so. This can be a bit troublesome though as it's fast speed and fantastic battery life are a result of aggressive task killing and limiting background processes. This frequently causes issues for some apps that are working in the background or even streaming audio. This can be remedied with exceptions but still worth mentioning.
2 sim cards can be used nativly and it is hands down the best software I have ever used for managing two sims. No other Chinese phones have come close to that level of plug and play with hot swapping sims.
The most exciting part though and exclusively what I paid for is the sensor and photo AI. The zoom is simply incredible. You will not believe it at first. It zooms optically for a very low noise zoom, pushing the limit triggers the AI which does a fantastic job of stabilization at up to 50X. It is even able to capture color and exposure accurately at range. The night mode is also incredibly powerful but demands a tripod or very steady hand. Essentially a long exposure but with the miracle of the sensor that somehow fills in the details at a level your eye can not even see.

I've been using this phone for 3 weeks. The most impressive thing about this phone in my opinion is not the camara. Don't get me wrong, the camera is as good as everybody else said. However, I don't think the image quality here can replace what I get from my DSLR or my mirror less. It's just above average when compare to other phones in the market and having full set of lenses that fits in my pocket is quite a new experience.
Now, back to what I love the most about P30 Pro, it's the battery. When I opened the box for the first time, the phone had 33% of battery. I received the phone at work around 10:30am and didn't have a chance to recharge it. I ran around all day that day and used the phone like usual, making calls, texts, emails, read documents, web search, GPS, etc. Only didn't have a chance to watch video or listen to music. By 9:30pm, 11 hours later, the battery went down to 1% and I just barely made it home. So, 33% for 11 hours with normal usage is pretty good for me considering my old phone can never last more than 4 hours in the same circumstance.
After the first day, I always start the day with 95-100% battery. My days normally start at 8:30am to 10:00pm. I've always come home with 40% left after 13.5 hours. This is definitely new to me. No more powerbank, no more looking around for an outlet to charge my phone, no more fighting over the charger with my wife and kids when we're outside, no more rushing to my bedroom to charge my dying phone when I get home, etc. I can use my P30 Pro as much as I like when I'm outside without worrying about putting the phone in battery saving mode. When I came home, now I can relax, sit in the living room a bit, spend time in the kitchen a bit. Unlike before that I have to run to my bedroom to charge my phone right away because it's about to die in 5 minutes. What a difference sensation.
Just an FYI, my old phone was a 2 years old Samsung with 3600mAh battery. My wife's is a year old iPhone that battery always run out at the end of the day. P30 Pro last all the way through the night.
The second best thing about this phone is the charger. I used Samsung all these years and very familiar with their fast charge. However, I've never seen anything like Huawei's Super charge. It's just crazy fast.
A lot of times at night, I went to bed and forgot to charge my phone. Woke up at 5:00am to realize it and start charging the phone. Usually, the phone has about 35% left. After taking shower and getting dress which took me about 20 minutes, once I'm done the phone will be charged up to 90% already. If I waited 15 minutes more, it'll go up to 100%.
Couple days ago, I spent a lot of time waiting for people so I watch a lot of videos to kill time. I used up the battery more than usual but still had 26% left by the time I got home. So, watch and stream video consumed more power but wouldn't completely drain out the battery of P30 Pro.
Enough with the battery, as I mentioned before, the camera is good for as long as you don't expect the full frame or APS-C quality. For smartphone, However, this is absolutely the best for still photos.
Video, unfortunately, is another matter. Although P30 Pro can shoot 4k but it's only limit at 30fps. If you're looking for a better video capability, Samsung S10+ is a better choice because it can shoot 4k60. The P30 Pro, on the other hand, is limit even at 1080p because it's only does 60fps while S10+ can go upto 1080p240. Big difference.
The screen is only full HD, not quad like S10+ but it's still AMOLED and looks good with every tasks. I have no complain about the quality of the screen. In fact, I already dropped this phone once in my garage, face down. There's no crack or scratch and still works perfectly fine so I know it's durable.
The Emui, I don't know why people complain so much about Huawei interface. Some people said it's look too much like iPhone with all the apps present on screen. Well, there's a drawer too if you choose to use it and make it feels more like Samsung. To me, there are some features I like that easier than Samsung and there are some features that's harder as well. No matter which phone you choose, it'll never be 100% perfect so why complain?
I will conclude my review here that this P30 Pro is one of the best in the market right now, especially the battery and charger. I might have something else to add but that'd be in the future.
Add comment 1: I was so busy lately and only have a chance to walk around a bit last night. So, I'd like to add some photos I took with P30 Pro. The first 3 photos just to show the difference between each lenses from wide angle to 10x zoom (actually, it's more like 16mm, 27mm and 270mm prime).

Ever since the Huawei p20 pro I no longer consider apple in the mix. This phone is amazing, fast and the camera, the camera is like hollywood style, the low light pictures tuen out amazing, and it has a telescopic camera. ergo is great and it is dual sim, I use Att card in the USA and have chips for Canada Brasil and Mexico and the phone works great in all locations. It included an earphone jack adapter for headphone thatnhave the traditional jack as well as a set of usb c head phones. Also one reviewer claimed it does not record in 4K, that is an untrue statement. It's a good phone, but before you decide to buy it you would like to know this :
1 - It's slippery, you will loos it, order a flip cover to protect it and give you a good grip.
2 - It's a USB-C connector, so you can not charge or connect it with your old u-USB cable.
3 - You can not connect your lovely KOSS porta pro headseth, as there is no jack plug, unless you have a USB-C to jack adapter.
4 - If you don't have bluetooth in your car, there's no jack to connect the sound, unless you have a USB-C to jack adapter.
5 - The wide angle is nice, not a lot, but nice to have.
6 - The tele-zoom is nothing but impressive, and so are the low light capabilities.
Where most phones has a USB connector and a jack for the headseth, this phone has a USB-C connector that can connect a USB-C earpiece with microphone (included). So if you want to both charge and listen to music via a jack connector, you need a combined audio / USB splitter cable to do both at the same time.
Not staying with the standard solution here and keeping the audio jack is the only mistake they've made I think.

My support for Huawei is because I've been using this brand before and has a great quality at a fair price (not like other overpriced brands).

I've used a 2016 Google Pixel for the past couple years and needed to upgrade when that phone recently died.
The P30 lite has a gorgeous screen with a tiny notch at the top - which I did not find distracting. The software is not stock android, but generally looked beautiful, functioned well, and had no bad habits. The software operates well and does a lot of thoughtful things that I appreciate.
The phone has a suite of "built-in" apps that you can delete, but they will only re-install themselves at the next Google Play update. Annoying. I don't know why phone makers still do this in 2019. This is more of a nitpick though.
What isn't a nitpick is the general sluggishness feeling of the phone. It feels slower than my 3 year old Pixel. Opening and closing of windows, zooming in on images, and just general operation feel less snappy than I would expect them to. Most people won't find this offensive, but if you're coming from a more powerful phone - even an older one - you'll notice it immediately.
For $270 its a great buy and for the price it would ordinarily be a five star phone. However given the alternatives, I'm afraid I have to ding it a star for the lack of speed. I'm returning mine for a Mi 9t.

I needed a replacement phone, due to a swollen battery on my Huawei Mate SE (I discovered overcharging a cell battery increases gasses in the battery from a phone tech, so don't leave your phone constantly charging, folks). I could have had the battery replaced by a tech for $55, but decided to treat myself to a slight upgrade. I was very happy with the Mate SE, so I went to Youtube for reviews of Huawei phones. After seeing a number of very favorable reviews of the P30 Lite, I ordered this phone late last Saturday, and received it the following Monday.
I had debated spending $500 or more for a "high end" phone, but learned a lot of the technology in more expensive phones is dedicated to photo-taking technology. I'm not a selfie-addict, so I let common sense take over, and opted for a phone in the $300 range (I found a vendor that sold this phone for $259, and 2 day delivery- I didn't want to wait a week in the event my old phone died).
The phone comes with the described accessories- USB-C cord, screen protector, charging brick, and a very thin, rubberized case. The phone is very sleek and slippery. I'd suggest putting the case on immediately, so it doesn't slide out of your hand. I originally placed it on a glass table top, and it slid all over the place.
The phone has a massive 128 gig internal storage capacity. I put a 128 gig SD card in the 2nd slot. I can't imagine what I'd fill the phone with, but I think most of us have discovered over time that we tend to fill our phones up with pics and music. I'll have plenty of room to download Netflix vids to watch when I'm on a treadmill.
Out of the box, the phone was charged to about 56%, and was loaded with Android version 9.
The on speaker at the bottom is very loud. I tend to link to a bluetooth speaker or headphones for music and videos anyway. I haven't tried a phonecall on speakerphone yet.
The phone seems only able to pick-up the 2.5 Ghz channel on your wireless network.
Exporting all my apps and settings from my old phone to the P-30 was almost seamless, using Huawei's Phone Clone app (you can obtain it in the Google Play Store, for your old phone). This turns both phones into hotspots, and you keep both phones close to each other, and 99% of my apps and settings were exported.
By default, ALL your apps will be displayed over multiple screens. I thought I would have to spend hours arranging my apps, but discovered the setting (see attached pic) for "Home screen style" under Settings>Home screen & Wallpaper>Home Screen Style> then select the bottom choice, "Drawer." This brought almost all my app icons I had from my old phone, where I nested similar apps in their own "drawers" labeled "music," "tools,' etc. This saved me HOURS of work. All your apps will now be in a drawer that looks like a circle with 3 rows of 3 dots. You can then drag whatever apps out, and align them how you wish. If you drag one app into another, you create a- I think they're called "drawers" which you can then label. This helps categorize apps.
"Ease of use" is relative. If you're new to the Android world, going through all the settings can be daunting, and there's LOTS of settings under the hood. I'm still discovering many. I appreciate built-in apps, like App Lock, which enables you to protect your apps like email, and banking by preventing use by other people. You unlock the app either by your fingerprint, or passcode.
I enabled fingerprint and facial recognition to unlock the phone. The responsiveness is instantaneous. One trick with the fingerprint scanner on the rear of the phone: when looking at pictures, you can use a finger to swipe to the next picture, so you can view a gallery of of photos with one hand, instead of two.
There is a notch at the top of the phone, which can be hidden via settings.
I find the camera much faster than my old phone, and more variety in how to take take photos. The photos are crisp, and capture colors fairly accurately. Are they iPhone quality pics? No. The camera isn't a big deal for me, but it's nice to have a camera that takes good quality photos. The digital zoom works very well. Sending pics via MMS seem fine to me, unlike another reviewer.
There's no native internet calling feature, but there's 3rd party apps that support that (but you will be issued a new phone number).
Scrolling is fast and smooth.
I found one little quirk: When viewing Youtube, the video is about 20% smaller than the screen. You can go fullscreen using your thumb and forefinger to stretch to fullscreen. It may be a power saving feature; I'm not sure.
Huawei is known for its extremely long power use. You'll have to experiment in Settings to find the one right power setting for you.
There's plenty more features to be discovered, but at this price point, this phone is a winner.

This phone has met my expectations thus far. I needed a cheap but dependable phone, and I think this phone meets that need. It is very lightweight. My husband has a similar Huawei that is a few years old and his phone is much heavier. However, the weight doesn't seem to indicate that the phone is cheap by any means. It holds battery well, charges extremely quickly, has decent sound quality for shows and movies, and take better pictures than my last phone did. The pictures are really good, but using the zoom is tricky as zoomed pictures generally come out blurry (but maybe it's just my shaky hand). The fingerprint sensor works perfectly. The phone seems intuitively designed. It is easy for me to navigate through apps and change settings. My only complaint is that I have a problem with calls dropping in areas where they didn't previously. However, I recently changed my service provider, so I have no way of knowing if the drop issue is related to the new phone or the new service provider. Overall, not a bad buy...Would buy it again.

My old phone with 16 gb worked very well for me last three years, but my usage started to demand more storage. The price is right for this 128 gb phone. I had it for one day now. Overall, I am quite happy with it. The lag time doing in negotiation is quite negligible to me and flow is quite smooth. I do not know how good the camera is, although the few pictures and videos I took were quite acceptable. I generally used a Canon SLR camera for photos, and this is just to be used for quickie and convenient use only. It did not detect my 5g or AC wifi, but somebody in the review has always pointed out, so it is within my expectation. Using speedtest with 2.4ghz wifi, I got 74.7 mbps download speed. I am not sure if it is just my cloud content or it is Google problem, but I like to warn that if you Google backup to install all the apps previously installed in the other phone, it created a display sleep problem. The phone would go to sleep every eight seconds if there was no activity, no matter what battery performance or sleep timeout setting I changed to. I had to solve the problem by resetting the phone to the original factory setting and reinstalling each application manually one by one through the play store. I got the solution from other users in the internet having the similar problem with Huawei phone and other brands phones so this maybe a common problem with the Google backup. Likely, it could be the content stored in this backup, but I do not care to find out as I do not have the problem any more. It also seems that I have an easier time to synchronize the windows 10 contact and calendar apps through the outlook.com with the phone built-in contact and calendar apps, than my old phone. It took me about three hours to re-install all the apps, about 40 of them and to complete the email, contact and calendar setups.

I was one of the last holdouts with a windows phone, and knew I had to buy something to replace it. I had android years ago, so I thought I would just go back to it, plus apple doesn't make products in this price range really. My biggest fear was trying to transfer data, and it did prove to be trying and not completely successful. Got photos, music (had to buy a converter from wma to aac format) and my ringtone ok. Only got sms texts transferred using an app, but lost my mms and contacts. Oh well, I just made do. I am a very light smart phone user so..... not a big deal.
This phone itself, I really like. Ultimately popped in the sim card from windows phone and this one took off. Screen is great for me, I got my apps loaded and I am very satisfied with this phone. Photos are certainly good enough. I cannot seem to figure out how to get a shadow screen to open up when I take it out of my pocket, I always have to push the button. Probably a security thing. I don't use the fingerprint scanner, opted out of that so I cannot comment on it. Like that it has a headphone jack, and I added a 128 sd card.
I am a light user of this phone. I am not on it constantly. Probably twenty texts a day, the occasional phone call, some news reading, etc. So far the battery has lasted days for me. At least 3, and I was still at 40%. I turn off location, bluetooth and notifications since I don't use them daily and I am sure that helps with the battery.
This phone is faster than my nokia windows phone (950) which was one of their better phones at the time. For under $300 I think this is a fantastic phone. My understanding is that this phone will be supported into the future, even if Huawei is banned from Google support, as a kind of grandfathering for products already in consumer hands. It is a pretty phone (peacock blue) and feels solid to me. I wouldn't hesitate to buy another.
UPDATE 8/27/2019 As this is an international version, the android stuff is not as up to snuff as getting a US Version phone from ATT. One thing that I noticed after some use which bugged me, is that the resolution of the attached photos I would send in the messaging app was very poor. Blurry and no detail, it really toned down the resolution. The answer was to change messaging apps from the stock android to something else. I tried TEXTRA, and voila, the photo resolution improved immensely. Problem solved.

Also I have AT&T service and I did not need to call AT&T to activate my phone I just put in the SIM card and the phone worked. I like the features of the scrolling screenshot and the time limit that you can set on screen time. the camera on this phone is much better then the camera on my LG Stylo 4 I had previously. However the camera is not as good as my husband's LG G5. Setting up the fingerprint scanner was easy and fast and I like that it allows me fast access to the phone. Overall I am giving this phone 5 stars. also as a side note the case and screen protector that is included with the phone and the headphones are not the greatest quality but they are good enough to get you started and hold you over until your case arrives. Using device in EU, phone is GSM unlocked and everything's working! The only thing you'll need is to set up APN to your specific mobile network provider and disable the AT&T bloatware. Flashing the phone with ULM kdz firmware is quite easy (tutorials can be found online) and has an option to keep the existing files. It will remove all the bloatware and make the phone eligible to the upcoming Android Pie update. Recommended!
Update (05.08.19.) - Can now be updatable to Android 9 by flashing firmware version V350ULM20D. [Aware - Existing files/applications will be removed. If necessary, an LG Backup can be made on SD card to later be restored.]

I looked over a lot of phones looking for a replacement aging nexus 6, pocophone looked good but has questionable carrier compatibility and a lot of other unlocked phones in the >$300-400 range. All the budget phones had some serious down side, missing some key feature or just a low spec components. Then I stumbled on to the LG V35 and specs were on par with much pricier phones, the screen is oled witch I prefer and better than 1080, had expandable memory, cameras very good, battery hold charge for a long time. I was a little worried about LG as had bad experience with nexus 5x in the past, but looking at the reviews those issues were resolved. I also looked at the V40, but not a fan of the notch, and it is more money with similar specs. So my opinion is this is the best phone for the money right now, yes its been released a year ago, but compared to current phones in the price range V35 beats them no question. It is odd that this phone is not more popular, I guess at release $900 price tag scared people and then it faded out of the spotlight.
What I did not like: I am coming from a 6 inch phone the older wider screen, this screen is a little narrower. It is still good size, length wise about the same. When watching youtube vertically feels like a smaller screen. It is a little less bright than my old phone, could be a good thing as nexus was too bright at lowest setting when using at night. Coming off of stock android, I don't like LG and ATT bloatware and skins. The shareware is not a deal breaker, nothing that can't be worked around, but thought I mention it.
So I'm happy with the purchase and with the better components this phone should last me for a while, highly recommend this phone.

A quick trip to the ATT store and the SIM card was replaced and the IMEI changed in the system and now all works well!
Edit: It's been 2 months and I still like this phone. I purchased a second one for my wife. There are a couple of minor annoyances. The automatic brightness control dims the display a little too much in dark rooms. It's supposed to learn based on my adjustments over time, but, in spite of my adjusting it every time, it still dims it a bit too much. Also, I had set up the phone to unlock when the screen is tapped twice. But it kept waking up and calling 911 when it bounced around in my pocket. So I turned off the double tap wake up feature.

I will have a small review below this message and my information for Tracfone/Non-AT&T users below the primary phone review.
This phone at only $300 is a solid device compared to other mid-range phones released in 2019. After 2 weeks of use, I can say that this is an excellent choice for people who want the Snapdragon 845's performance at a somewhat affordable price. LG's OS is another bonus, feeling close to stock android and feeling super fast. Android 9 greatly increases the speed and adds nice extra features, but there sadly is no Dark/Night mode to conserve battery. The cameras are amazing and get even better when you port Google Camera over to it. The build quality is solid, but without a case, it is quite a fingerprint magnet. Sound from Bluetooth and the 3.5mm headphone jack are well above average with loud and clean audio. The screen's 6 inch display at 2880x1440 resolution looks amazing and content from Snapchat, Facebook, and Instagram look great with accurate colors. The biggest downside to the device is that the battery isn't very impressive for the price and if battery is a serious concern for you, I'd get a Samsung A70. The phones 18W fast charge capabilities help quite a bit with average charge time being around 1 hour and 20 minutes from 0% to 100%. Overall, this phone is excellent and provides high end features in an affordable mid-range package.
A message to all Tracfone/Non-AT&T service users:
This is an AT&T branded phone. While it is GSM unlocked, it still runs off of AT&T's network and all phone updates (Android 9 Pie and security updates) all come from AT&T and will not be available until you are on their network. This does not mean you need AT&T to get the updates, but you do need an AT&T compatible Sim Card from your service providers Bring Your Own Phone program to receive them. After setting up the Sim Card in the new phone, you'll need to create an APN to use mobile data (at least I needed to on Tracfone). After the phone is fully functional with call, text and mobile data, you should receive the updates within 2-5 days after activating the phone with your service provider. Again, as long as you buy and activate the phone with an AT&T branded Sim Card, you will receive all available updates for your phone. My phone took 2 days to receive the updates and I have had no problems with Tracfones service.

First of all, I want to clear up some stuff about the carrier of this phone.
The version of the phone that is being sold here is the V35PAWM, the AT&T unlocked version of the phone. From what I understand, it will work with GSM carriers without modification. However, I wanted to use the phone with Google Fi. It is quite easy in this case to flash the phone with the V35OULM kdz found here, no urls allowed in reviews, but it can be found on the LG firmwares website. I used the tutorial on the Flash Stock Roms website.
To be clear, the phone should work with GSM carriers without this process. However three are some advantages of flashing the kdz. No more AT&T bloatware, quicker updates (I have heard that some people using the AT&T software with a different carrier are not getting the android 9 update). For Google Fi specifically, some features of the service are not available without using a completely compatible phone. Flashing the OULM software makes the phone "completely" unlocked and compatible.
Now about the device itself.
I bought this to replace a Pixel 1 hat had picked up in preparation for an extended trip to Europe. However, the Pixel 1 was very buggy and rather outdated. The LG V35 has more than effectively replaced that phone. With the updated kdz it actually seems to work better with Fi than the picel did and the breadth of options within the os are overwhelming in a positive way. The screen resolution can be changed along with the way the volume interface works for example. Another nice touch is LG's theme options. I am using a theme called Pix Color. This applies a system wide dark mode and also makes the on screen buttons look like those on the pixel, a design that I prefer to LG's. However, the buttons can be hidden to take advantage of the whole screen retaliate, something that can not be done on the Pixel devices and some other android phones.
Speaking of the screen, it is huge and beautiful. The POLED panel looks quite good. My only complaint about the phone so far is actually that I think it is a bit too big, though I realized that is the current design trend. I much preferred the size of the LG G6 that I used to use.
Great phone overall, no real complaints so far.

I had to give my iPhone 7 to my son, had no desire to spend $1000 or eve $750 for a new flagship phone, saw this one at $299 & thought- "why not?' The phone was every bit as good as the reviews led me to believe it would be. The screen is amazing, so much bigger, brighter and more dynamic than my old iPhone's was, it's fast, smooth and has an excellent camera. I'm not really a heavy phone user, but I do spend some time every day on Duo to video chat with my kids, read news feeds, check emails, play some light games, call & text quite a bit and the battery always lasts the full day. Unfortunately I'm having to return the phone simply because it's so much bigger than my iPhone was, once I put a case on it it was just too big too carry around in my work environment. If I spent much time watching YouTube videos or playing graphic intensive games, I wouldn't hesitate to keep this phone, the screen and processor are that good. I'll probably just end up playing it safe and getting a refurbished iPhone 7, even though it costs more than this one and has a smaller, less vivid, LCD screen. I would recommend this phone and this seller though without hesitation to anyone in the market for a flagship level phone at a midrange price- especially if they're used to today's phone size ranges being on the big side.

What is this device, bought from MobileExpress !? Bought used, however scratches on the screen where not disclosed up-front! And the fact that it is an AT&T phone was not disclosed either! And there's no Android 9 updates, while my friends did receive it, USB-C to HDMI is not working !? I cannot recommend such device, far less from this seller!

I'm quite happy with this phone, particularly for the money. My most recent previous phones were a Samsung Galaxy 6 S active, then a Galaxy 7 Active. I liked both of those phones, good features and very rugged design, but after the 7 developed lines in the screen twice and Samsung wouldn't repair it the second time, though it's a known issue with that model, I decided to bail on them and try something different.
The V35 has some good points. Fast charging with Qi capability, real headphone jack, and expandable memory were the main selling points for me. It's definitely an ATT phone, which I'm OK with as I'm with ATT and will be in the foreseeable future with my wife's corporate discount. I get 5G connectivity in most of the parts of Chicago I frequent, even (surprisingly) in the downtown subway. The Wi-Fi calling works well, which it didn't with the Samsungs.
The screen is fine, good color and resolution. I rarely watch any video on it, but when I have it's been OK. The speaker is pretty wimpy, I do wish it were louder, if the phone is in another room there's a pretty good chance I won't hear it when I have a call or notification. The Samsungs were definitely louder. Bluetooth audio is good, and works well in my car.
The camera is OK. Though the pixel count is similar to my DSLR it's no contest when you look at the same scene photographed with the two of them. No surprise there, but it shows you pixel count is a bad way to compare digital cameras. Color accuracy is so-so, but I don't care all that much as I won't use it for anything important.
My only real negative is the rear power button / fingerprint reader. I'm adapting, but would definitely prefer a side power button.
Battery life is OK, but not anything special. The fast charge offsets that somewhat, when it gets low you can get back up to 100% with a quickness, even using the Qi charging.
One thing I do really like is the 2 year warranty, if they trust their engineering enough to offer that warranty it makes me believe the phone is pretty well constructed.
So overall for the 300 clams it ran me I'm very satisfied, and can recommend it as a good value for the money.

The phone was in fact new and unlocked. Works very well with Straight Talk. Remember to punch out the nano-sized card and place it in the slot at the front of the SIM holder. After you get set up with the carrier you will need to google the APN settings for that carrier and manually enter them into the phone. A high quality phone at a super price.

I've had the phone for about 2 weeks now. In general, I love the phone, so far. It was unlocked and easy to set up on the AT&T service that I have. There are preloaded apps, but I have been able to remove one's I don't want. Although, I have only removed a couple, so I'm not sure if they are all removable..The only thing I'm not fond of is the stationary screen to the left of home. But apparently that is becoming the standard for almost all phones and is something I will get used to. The battery life is good...I thought it might be better. But to be honest I use my phone like a mini computer and play on it a lot. No major concerns or complaints.
If you are an AT&T customer this is a great deal. Great specs on the phone for a bargain price. Definitely happy with this purchase.

First off, this is a great device for the price. For the week or so I used it, I was very happy with the performance and battery life. Ultimately, I returned the unit because even though it is unlocked, it still has the AT&T firmware load. You are not able to update firmware on the device unless you have AT&T service or an active AT&T SIM. I should have done more research before I bought this one, as this seems to be a widely known issue. Personally, being stuck on a year old firmware without ability to get later versions or security updates is a big issue.

I accidentally drowned my LG v40 & needed to replace it. After doing some research I found this to be the best deal at $300. This is a High end phone at mid-range price. A $800 plus phone does not have much more to justify the price. I'm satisfied with my purchase.....such a underrated phone.
I'm with AT&T and all works perfect. Happy to have Android pie 9.0. For those on another carrier and unable to update to 9.0......why not buy a cheap AT&T pre paid card and update. Another option would be to borrow a friends AT&T SIM card and update.

Hi all. I was in the market for a new, Unlocked phone. A coworker showed me his V35. Thought it looked great. Since I am an AT&T Prepaid Customer, This phone was Perfect. As it is an AT&T phone. Now people can actually reach me. Pull the phone out of the locker(At work) and see Missed Calls and Text messages received. The Sony kept loosing the connection. The only real issue I have with it is, The Finger Print Reader. Can't read mine. Might not be the phone. When I worked as a DoD Civilian, They had Trouble getting my fingerprint for my ID. Took them several tries. After the 2nd attempt at setting mine up, I gave up on it. And chose a Pin. Even connected it to my 2019 Hyundai Kona.

It works with Freedom Mobile and is roaming on AT&T.
Great cellphone and it was a steal even for $380!
Update of 03/2020: still running strong, great screen and screen size, good cameras, great battery life and a very fast and smooth performance.

I received a brand new LG V35 ThinQ phone with charger in a sealed box. It is AT&T branded with their software installed, which was fine for me because I use AT&T for service. I just couldn't bring myself to pay what AT&T wants for the exact same phone in their stores. Put my SIM card in, and after several software updates everything is working great including VOLTE and Wi-fi calling (with a postpaid account). I can't attest to it being unlocked as I have not tried another carrier's SIM card in it. I'm coming from an older Moto X and find the LG interface just as intuitive. Great Android experience at a fantastic price!

Been using it a couple days now no issues. I think LG hit a home run with this one.
( Pros=All good for me ) ( Cons=Nothing at this point. ) If anything changes I will re post. I did not rate finger print reader as I do not use it. My job= IT-Admin and Support 25 years. I'm on phone a lot. First day I used it, I bet screen never went off, set for 10 min to sleep. Had 20% left bout 9 Hours. 1/2 bright, Wi-Fi=on, Data=on, Location=on, BT=on
It charged up in apox 1hr and change. ( it did upgrade to 9 (Pie) and that seems stable to ( so far ).
I use a regular Panasonic BT phone at home so i do not have to carry this one around and using BT and Wifi data and Calling at same time was no problem, smooth and clear. My old phone had issues doing this ( all at once ). Thx LG

I love this phone. It's amazing, and it's such a great value. The battery lasts two days on one charge with normal usage (browsing and chatting throughout the day, no calls, lots of email and Twitter). The screen is gorgeous. The fingerprint reader works like a champ. I have absolutely zero complaints about this phone. It's amazing and I love it.

The headphone jack just stopped working, before the phone was a year old. The socket is now completely loose. Headphone jacks no longer snap in, and the phone will no longer recognize any set of headphones I try to plug in. It now only plays through the phone's speaker.
I chose this phone for its high quality dac, to listen to music at work, and when I travel. Originally, I was pleased with it. It used to produce noticeably more clarity than my laptop or previous phone, when using the same headphones (OPPO PM-3) and music files. I wanted the phone to last and tried to be gentle when plugging and unplugging the headphones, which I would do perhaps 2-3 times a day on workdays.
Originally, the battery would hold its charge for 2-3 days with Bluetooth and wireless enabled, but very few applications running. 9 months later, under the same usage, it will last less than a day.
Given the strongly sealed case, the battery does not appear to be replaceable, at least by myself. Perhaps a repair shop can. But I had hoped to get a longer life then 9 months before the battery began to degrade so noticeably.
Everything else about the phone was between good and very good:
The screen is very good, the primary camera is... okay, not great in the dark, even with flash.
I did like that this phone came with fewer bloat apps to disable and remove than my previous samsung phone, though it still had quite a few.

I literally bought this on the day that apple released the new ios 13 update...and my iPhone 6 wasn't able to download that update...or an future updates. I have had enough of Apple telling me when it's time to purchase a new iPhone, so i researched alternatives. After a lot of collaborating, i landed here. The LG V35 Thinq. I am so happy that i did my homework. Good battery life, amazing camera, great sound, wifi and bluetooth connection (which was really important to me. You are a fool if you pay $1000 for a phone that you can get for $300.
The only downside for me:
I am on 3 network. I'm using this phone in the USA and i prefer using AT&T rather than T-mobile, as i am on 'feel at home'. It doesn't seem to stay on AT&T, no matter if i manually choose it or not. It always switches to T-mobile.
Anyways, that is a minor convenience...i love this phone.
GOODBYE APPLE!!!!

I have had LG phones for a while now. I've Loved LG phones I've bragged about LG phones I had the LG 3 and the LG 6 they both lasted Way Beyond the two-year commitment. First off, like many have noted the phone I received is an ATT device. Since I am an ATT customer, it worked without issue and I can't say for sure if the phone is unlocked or not. For those wondering if the phone gets Android 9 (pie), yes it does..at least if you are on ATT. The most recent update, July 2019, improved battery life significantly.
What I look for: Camera (Image Quality both bright and low light), processor, screen, headphone jack.
Camera:
I've been shooting images for nearly 30years and seldom leave home without my DSLR..but when I do I'd like my phone camera to be able to capture decent amounts of detail in various lighting conditions. I wouldn't say this is the best camera, but it surely holds its own. The lowlight mode is a bit slow, but it's working it's magic combining pixels. I've attached a few photos. All in all I'd say it's performance slots in to the upper mid-range/lower high-end.
Processor/Memory: Qualcomm SnapDragon 845 (previous years high-end) + 6GB RAM. This combo keeps the phone moving right along even with Android 9...photo apps and games alike are snappy.
Screen: QuadHD (4k) OLED screen. Really can't get much better than this, no notch, true deep blacks...color reproduction is fantastic...but it is dim. I crank the screen up to 80%+ under direct sunlight and it's still tough to see.
Headphone Jack: It matters to me because I enjoy Audio as much as I do photography. So naturally I love to be able to enjoy my wired AKG headphones. And with a dedicated DAC built into the phone, I can definitely say it's sound reproduction is by far superior to phones in this price range and higher if using the headphone jack. The bad though is that the overall volume it outputs is on the low side. In a noisy room I need the volume to be at a minimum of 50% to hear the music and even higher to be immersive. Volume through Bluetooth is fine.
All in all I'm a happy camper with this phone. I've been a iPhone user since the 6s+, 7+, XR..chasing the camera...and now back to android with this LG V35 thinQ. If performance, value, and features is what you're after..this is the one.

As my old LGK10 was dying, I desperately needed a new phone at a reasonable price. While I was willing to buy a new, alternate brand of phone outright, my carrier would not yield on their push for a monthly financing plan. If any of these irritants sound familiar, or you just want a great phone, this could be a good choice for you.
I received a new, unlocked LG35 thinQ phone.. It arrived in an unsealed box with an ATT logo like the merchandise you buy from the carrier. The product contained the phone , a plug and power cord, an instruction book, lens wipe and SIM slot pin. You do NOT get a SIM card, ear buds or a glass protector.
This phone has triple the storage of the K10 (64 ) vivid color and pixel display and an optional AI photo system for the camera. The normal Google installs, basic ATT apps and LG apps (new since my orig LG 10 purchase) ARE also included on the device. I don't think it had too much bloatware. Phone audio is excellent and I noticed it is hitting both 5G and 4G networks.
The phone is "Qi" enabled so the wireless charging could help avoid the bent prung problems that accelerate damage when using wall chargers. I had no problems setting up my fingerprint reader, but this model can also be programmed for facial recognition, voice print, traditional passwords, or knock patterns.
ATT was very helpful in transferring data and contact lists etc to the new device. My old SIM and micro SD fit into the same slot.
The best point by far was the price!! This truly is a wonderful deal on a wonderful product ! Upon placing my Amazon order, I even received a link from the distributor to further product support. LG fans should not pass this up.

I bought this device to activate on Straight Talk GSM, and as advertised, this product is unlocked. AT&T's bloatware is relatively unintrusive, and after cleanup it doesn't take up much of the device's internal storage.
With that said, it's an excellent phone with few compromises.
Overall, the LG V35's build quality is excellent. Beautiful glass exterior with a stylish design reminiscent of a Galaxy S9+. It feels great in the hand, even with a bulky impact case on. The 1440p OLED screen is fantastic as well. It's nearly as good as a Samsung panel.
Performance-wise, this device is quite snappy. The Snapdragon 845 and 6GB of RAM make multitasking a breeze, and there is no lag in LG's stock ROM at all, even with all the apps I have installed. The LTE modem delivers outstanding performance, as does the Wi-Fi modem. I've never been able to get 70mbps download over LTE in my back yard, but now I can.
The camera is great as well. The rear cameras take great still shots, and the front camera is more than adequate for Snapchat. Video is also quite good. The images are very vivid and crisp.
Battery life is acceptable, and it isn't really a problem if you have the included Fast Charge brick on hand.
Audio is also pretty good. It comes with a high-quality DAC for 3.5mm headphone audio playback, which sounds excellent. The mono speaker is decent for voice calls and talk shows, but is pretty shrill for music.
It does come with AT&T-specific features like Visual Voicemail, voice over LTE, and WiFi calling, but I have yet to get them working on Straight Talk.
My only concern is software updates. The included software is pretty good, but the security patches only reach November 2018, and LG is notorious for being slow with software updates. If you absolutely need up to date security patches, beware.
I would normally expect a phone like this to cost $700, and even then it's a reasonable price, especially if you're an AT&T customer. However, it's only $350, and it is an excellent deal. Would recommend.
I have cricket service and it works perfectly

I wanted to upgrade my LG V20 on tmobile's network, but didn't want to pay 800+ or lock myself into a 2year contract so I was looking at cheap phones. I came close to buying a renewed/used Essential or similar for 150, but then came across the ATT unlocked V35 thinq. I was very worried about using an ATT phone on tmobile, but figured I'd try it.
I'm so glad I pulled the trigger. After receiving the phone I realized I may not be able to get updates as I'm not on ATT's network.. I then noticed this phone was an official google-fi phone, which should mean its 100% compatible with tmobile, and should also allow me to get updates.
It was easy to use the LG software to update the phone to the latest firmware for Google-Fi (listed as GFI on LG's website), leaving me with a debloated OS that will allow me to obtain future updates. As far as using the GoogleFi on Tmobile's network, it works perfect. The phone's hardware has the same bands as the V20 so I wasn't expecting to get the 600mhz band. I'm getting at least as good reception as my V20 and speed tests are perfectly fine (140mb in some cases).
I've been hyping this to everyone I know who might want a new phone and may be on tmobile, att, or google-fi. Yes it's not a 2019 phone with the latest bands but its easily better then many phones and was very much over-looked in 2018.

I ordered this phone as a new unlocked gsm phone. I recieved an email from the seller before the phone arrived about contacting them for an unlock code if needed when trying to activate on my network. I've bought unlocked phones for years and never had to input any code to make it work. They assured me that the phone was new though. I got the phone, inserted my sim card and powered up to an AT&T logo along with the standard AT&T bloatware, I'm on Cricket so its the same network and the data and calling worked. After a little while playing with the phone i noticed that on a bright white background the center third of the screen looked dingy/yellow, brown. I did some research and found no related issues to this particular phone but some problems with other OLED screens having ugly whites. I changed the screen tones and it was a little better. Several hours later after playing an online game with my son I set the phone down on the table and it sounded like a thin piece of plastic, I looked and found the the back upper left corner of the glass was pulled away from the frame of the phone with a very noticeable gap, I could see glue residue where it should be sealed at. That was the final straw, I immediately started the return on Amazon, swapped my sim card back to my old phone, boxed it up and sent it back the next day.
The phone was very smooth. It took good pictures and played games at the highest resolution and frame rate. This particular phone did not come close to the quality I expected after reading so many great reviews.
A couple of days later I found this same phone through Cricket for 299. I went to the store and put my hands on the last one instock. The screen was excellent with clean bright white and no signs of the back coming loose from the frame. I bought the phone and have enjoyed it since. I also found that the phone Cricket is selling is truely unlocked, it doesn't even have Cricket logo on starting and the only bloatwear is from LG. I recommend this phone but be careful where you buy it from.

I seriously love this phone. I had a samsung Galaxy s 5 and it fi ally bit the dust... I wanted an android and my dad reccomended an LG.. The reviews on this I e were good...i spent more than i had origionally planned but everyone said great phone for $350 Which when I dont have to make payments on a phone is actually a good price...they werent wrong! I'm not used to the speed or the capacity of what it can do! I have been using the battery a lot just caise i cant put it down. The only thibg i dont love is I couldnt immediatly figure out how to turn off the data. And use my Wi-Fi instead..but once I figured that out (the next day) I havent had issues. Also it takes a nano SIM card so i litterally went to AT&T with old and new phone and they took care of SIM card and phone transfer all done in 10 min. Was happy! I'm just sad i waoted so long to make the switch!!

Why do I like this phone? After 48 hours - here is my impression. This thing is FAST. Every app loads virtually instantly - connects very quickly. Its built for AT&T network and connects better to their network than any phone I have tried. What really sets this apart too is the sound quality. The EQ processing for car audio is awesome! Lots of control over the surround channels - bass etc. With headphones its even better! ---- it feels like a premium phone in the hand --- symmetrical and elegant. And NO NOTCH! This phone seems more supported by LG than others - several patches - up to and through Android 9 Pie. Camera quality is above average. It beats my friends Samsung S7 edge quite nicely - which beat by previous LG G5. $299 was pricing - cant get a better deal IMO.

I have contacted my carrier Safelink Wireless (it's programmed with an AT&T phone number though) numerous times and have received and installed 2 new sim cards and still cannot get WiFi Calling to enable! I was told by both Safelink and AT&T that these phones are locked to AT&T and the only way to get WiFi calling to work is you have to get your service directly from AT&T so they can lock your phone number into their service and not any other carrier like Safelink, Net10 or T-Mobile. It will not work even though I have an AT&T phone number... When I called up AT&T and even went in to an AT&T store they told me that they can't locate my account because I'm not directly with them and that my service account is with Safelink, THIS STINKS!!! I either have to stay with Safelink and forgo WiFi calling or cancel my service and setup new service directly with AT&T at a higher monthly fee just to enable WiFi calling... Other than that the phone itself is great, it's quick, fingerprint sensor works great, facial recognition also works very quick. I was even able to upgrade to Oreo 9.0 The only other downside to this phone is the battery life, my old phone was a BLU Vivo 8 and the battery in that phone would last up to 2 days, with the V35 using the same apps in the same manner as the old Vivo 8 this V35 lasts if I'm lucky maybe 1 day. Screen display is great, camera takes wonderful pictures and videos, sound is so so with only one speaker. It's much faster and the screen is much better than my Vivo 8 with no notch at the top of the screen. I even installed a 256mb microSD card into the available slot to store picts,videos and most apps to free up processing speed. For the price it's a great phone.

A great phone at an excellent price with excellent features such as light weight, dimensions, OLED display, RAM and the battery.
I bought this phone to use it outside the USA, the GSM is unlocked and everything works fine, I just had to configure the APN for my local network as discussed in other reviews. Originally the operating system came with version 8, I tried to update it to version 9 by myself but I used a ULM kdz firmware and it was not compatible with the phone version since this was a V35AWM10w, so I had to contact a specialist who was able to flashing the firmware to V350AWM20d and update the phone to android 9 Pie.

I am very satisfied with this purchase. I have always used an iPhone and finally made the decision to switch to an android. I am not disappointed! This phone is awesome. It is fast and takes really great pictures. Sometimes when using certain apps I have to press slightly more on the screen in order for it to pick up. This seems to happen with Facebook mostly so could just be the app. Portrait mode on the camera is amazing. Crystal clear images that almost look professional. The phone doesn't have a lot of memory but you are able to import a micro SD if needed. The sound quality on this phone is great, too; I don't really need a speaker anymore. It's also WATERPROOF which is a huge plus when having children. For $400 (which is HALF the price of a Galaxy) you get a great deal and value out of this phone! Remember though that this phone will only work with carriers like Cricket and AT&T, not Verizon or Sprint. I recommend this phone 100%!!

I moved to this phone from a galaxy s8, it is a great value for the cost. My galaxy s8 was working fine but the screen had cracked badly and was entirely too much money to fix. I was looking for something decent for less than the cost of repair so I stumbled upon this gem of a phone on amazon. First, I like the screen size ratio. It is wider than the galaxy and I like the display better like that. It also feels nice in my hand. Second, The repair costs are super reasonable. I had this phone 2 weeks and cracked the screen. Repair cost was $146 and was completed quickly and it looked and felt like a new phone when I got it back. This phone also has a 2 year warranty vs the others 1 year. This phone does tasks fast and has a great camera.

As other reviews have stated, this is not an unlocked phone. This is an AT&T Phone. There are no instructions on how to get the phone unlocked. The phone I received appeared new. For the price, I won't complain too much. The phone itself is nice and has nicer features than the phone I was looking to get at about the same price (Moto G7). I purchased this phone after having a G5 Plus. I, as many other people I'm sure, refuse to purchase a phone for $600+. The $350 I paid is ok.

No sim card with phone? Packaging says there is a SIM card. When I try to get Technical support I get the run around with the program to have them return my phone call. Very frustrating, can't make a complete review without sim card

This phone is replacing the Lg v20 that I loved for years. A little smaller but a powerhouse of a phone. Had it for a few days and loving it. I'm using it on Cricket Wireless ans no problems what so ever !

I was on the market for an S9+, but saw this phone for almost half the price but with the same specs. It was a no brainer of a purchase, and after having it for a week, im glad i found this steal. The screen is great, the phone is snappy and responsive, I havent messed around with the camera too much but based on professional reviews it's solid. The fingerprint reader is snappy, my phone battery easily lasts a day on above average usage. The device is waterproof, the design is pleasing and feels good to hold in the hand, feels solid. After a week of usage i have had no real complaints regarding this device. If you're on the market for a 2019 android flagship phone, you cant pass on this deal, not at this price.
For those worried about the unlocked nature of the phone, yes it is an unlocked At&t phone, but trust me, that doesnt matter. Just disable the At&t apps and boom, you'll be fine. I cant speak for its functionality on other US carriers, but I am from Jamaica, and it works perfectly on our Digicel Network.

I haven't had my phone that long, but I haven't found anything I don't like about it. I don't use the fingerprint reader, but that is personal preference. The camera takes very good quality pictures and the screen resolution is super! I've only had this phone for 1 week, but I would highly recommend it.

beautiful phone to bring to metro. easy to switch over from att "possession" - long as you input your previous metro phone's info: name, apn, mmsc, mcc, mnc, apn type (do not enter anything here), apn protocol, apn naming protocol into your network settings - so you can connect data to metro provided internet. also, you'll need to disable, uninstall a few att bits imcluded in this "unlocked," but not lg stock item. much simpler than it sounds. call metropcs - they'll get you started. whole set-up took me about 3 hours - much of it updating and downloading apps. figuring out what worked was relatively easy. i now have a wonderful "new" better phone at the $300 price point. yea for me!
I'm afraid I have to give a 3 star for false advertising because it says it comes unlocked but the phone is still locked.

phone works great, and despite the AT&T branding at startup it operates on my MVNO just fine. for the price you just can't beat all the features this phone has though. For a $300 phone this will blow the competition away in any side-by-side comparison.
sidenote, because the phone is unlocked it will NOT receive the android 9/pie update.

Moved from LG V10 to V35, V10 is still working good but I needed an upgrade. Once you use LG product and if you are loyal then its hard to look for other options.

I actually read privacy policies, and this is the scariest one I have ever seen. Not only does LG reserve the right to take all your information (location, contacts, pictures, videos, email, etc) for their thinQ AI and for Google Assistant, they also reserve the right to force Over-the-air updates which remove features from the phone and cannot be rolled back. You're paying $730 for LG to potentially spy on you, sell your personal data to everyone else, brick your phone and make you pay more to get it working again.
Pretty much no phone has privacy anymore, but this is the most eggregious violation of decency I've seen yet. It is pretty though... I wish I could have made it past the "agree to this privacy policy" screen to see what else it could have done.

Performance really suffered in that the OS did not seem optimized for the hardware (stutters and lags) but this was most evident in the camera software which would lock up during launch or during a photo capture, sometimes not even taking a photo. This was also reflecting in the poor battery life, very moderate use in good signal area resulted in 50% drain with only a few hours (mostly in standby). Wanted to really like this device but it didn't work out.

I bought this phone to replace my broken LG G5. All apps work fine except those for Basic and Premium Visual Voicemail. I spent 2+ hours on phone with Verizon to try to resolve the problem. No luck because this phone is not configured to allow those apps to work. I am back to dialing *86 to access voice messages. Pain in the neck!

Having issues connecting to at&t 4GLTE. I was finally able to get connected to AT&T 3G network after being at the AT&T store and on the phone for 2 hours. This phone is from the Latin American network provider Claro and the box instructions (all in Spanish) said LG Panama. This is my 3rd LG G series phone. I like the fit, simplicity, and performance but I dont think I will buy another phone from amazon.

Other than defects, which can happen in any brand and model, once we ordered a replacement this product seems to operate fine. Note that the G7 ThinQ does not have an identical user interface to the LG V35. G7 is much less intuitive to use or find desired settings and appears to be missing some useful settings or options found on the V35 model. Quality of materials is excellent and sound quality is above average, though not as good as as the Moto Droid Turbo 2 it replaced (the T2 had dual sizable front-facing stereo speakers). Given the choice again, now that we know the user interface difference, we would choose the V-series rather than G-series phone.

Before I start my review, I would like to mention that my previous phones were the Iphone 5, Samsung Galaxy S7, and a Samsung Galaxy S9. I will use the Galaxy S9 for a couple of examples since it’s the last phone I had (and my wife still has hers). Alright, hold on tight for this one because I got inspired lol…
PROS:
SCREEN - The first thing that with catch your attention is the screen. This screen is colorful, sharp, bright, and very attractive to the eye. It has a feature I’ve never seen on any other phone where it can boost the screen brightness at a very high level so its easy to use when on direct sunlight. Also, its flat which means no weird edge screen like the Galaxy S9 (this means no screen glare on the corners and tempered glass screen protectors are compatible).
CAMERA – The camera is very impressive with nice color enhancements. The COOLEST feature is the wide-angle lens. Its not a fisheye like the gopro, but it lets you take incredible photos from a very close distance.
BATTERY – yeah, I have no idea why people complain about the battery of this phone. Maybe is because they pay too much attention to the hardware. The truth is the phone lasts the entire day with absolutely no problem. I feel the battery performance is as good (if not better) than the Galaxy S9.
FACE RECOGNITION – The face recognition is fast…very fast. You don’t have to find the perfect angle or wait for it to unlock. I find it to unlock in 1 second or less.
SOUND – The sound its loud, clear, but when placed on a table it has no competition. It really beats the phones out there.
CONS:
CAMERA – Although the camera in general way better than the Samsung Galaxy S9, night photography (front camera) with the S9 turns out to be slightly better. This is because the S9 has double aperture.
SIDE BUTTON – This phone includes an extra button that activates google now. I do not use google now so it would be nice to be able to use this button as another shortcut such as camera, email, or any other thing.

The phone in and of it self is a good phone, however, it's not the US version (G710ULM) with a US warranty as advertised (3/8/19); it's the international version (G710EM) with no available US warranty.
One way to tell if you've been ripped off is to check the model number in "Settings/About Phone". If you have any other number other than G710ULM, you don't have the US version with a warranty. If a time comes when you need warranty service, you are sorry out of luck.
I contacted LG directly, provided LG with the IMEI number for the phone, and they confirmed the phone was intended only for in the UK, not for in the USA. LG also confirmed you cannot get a US warranty for it.
Another way to tell if you've been ripped off is to power off the phone and power it back on. If you see "Claro", and words in another language, you've been ripped off. "Claro" is a carrier in Guatemala, and is what the phone I received booted up with. Additionally, the phone had "Claro" bloatware installed on it, of which couldn't be uninstalled.
Additionally, there are compatibility issues with this phone for US carriers because it's an international version, not a US version. I have AT&T, and they've informed me phone calls should work, but there may be very slow data speeds because of network conflicts with the international version. I confirmed this with a data speed tests, and my data speeds were very inconsistant and very slow.

So I bought this at B&H with a big discount. It lists $120 less than this one, but it comes with several freebies that make the phone cost around $530ish . Tx&Sh are included. You get a tempered glass screen protector. And you get a pair of earbuds with mic.
Now the phone. I checked this out at T Mobile and was stunned by the screen. Loved the 19.5:9 ratio. It makes the phone bigger than my old one without making it too big. It still has to fit in my front pocket. Screen is so nice and android 8 is nice. The two things I look for in a phone besides calls, text and email is for photos and music.
Camera is very good. (With latest updates it's better than the iphone 7+) Maybe not the very best, but if you aren’t a YouTube reviewer you won’t be comparing it to 10 other phones. Took some videos and really liked them. Cool feature is you can pause the video, but keep it as one video file, just with breaks. It also has separate camera and video record buttons, just like my digital camera. No fumbling with a menu to switch between photo and video. Low light is good. Wide angle is really nice for indoor shots.
Music is a priority to me. I listen to music thru my car speakers all the time. I also need a headphone jack to do this, so that really limited my choices. I’m so glad LG kept the jack. The Quad DAC is awesome! It does make the music sound better even my car speakers. Boom box is nice, the speaker is very loud, probably the loudest you can get. Bass is absent until you place it on a table. Mids and highs are just fine.
Overall this is perfect for me. No messing with iTunes. I hate iTunes so much I will never buy an iPhone. All I want to do is add music effortlessly. Really just love everything about the phone.
2 month update:
The extended battery option definitely helps with battery life. I’m a light to medium user, so I often go two + days before charging.
Fast charge really is fast. It charges 1% per minute.
Google assistant is actually really cool, when it works. I really didn’t know what this was all about, but am finding that I use it a lot now. It’s just like Alexa, which I use all the time at home. So using this isn’t hard to get use to. The LG G7 has an always on listening mic so you just say ‘hey google’.
Most will complain about the LG skin on top of android. I actually like some of the features. The floating bar is useful and I use it everyday. I use the LG music player because googles music player is just an ad machine. No matter what setting I set, google music will eventually start pushing its paid services and music I have no interest in.
Super bright boost screen is actually useful. In broad daylight while wearing sunglasses, I can keep my sunglasses on and still see my screen. I’ve used boost more often than I thought I ever would.
So many unlock methods it’s ridiculous. I use in this order, face unlock, fingerprint unlock, knock code, voice unlock. I am finding that I wish the fingerprint unlock was in the screen instead of behind.
As a phone the size is really nice. Thin, kind of heavy and long. It reminds me of holding a home phone. When holding it up to my ear, the mic extends all the way to my mouth, it feels natural and not like a small toy the way most phones feel.
After several updates the camera is amazing! Some of the best photos I’ve seen. With latest updates photos are now better than the iPhone 7+. I now use my phone for all photos and videos and no longer use my digital camera, the quality is better and overall experience is better, faster and easier than my canon.
Loving this phone!

I received my platinum grey Lg G7 ThinQ in the mail yesterday. I bought a case and screen protector and everything, set up all my information and transferred my contacts... then I went to the store today to put it on a data plan and the Verizon gentleman told me it is not compatible. Don't believe the answered questions by the manufacturer that says it's compatible with Verizon. IT IS NOT! I repeat: IT IS NOT COMPATIBLE WITH VERIZON.
Also, I was playing around with the camera last night, and the pictures really leave more to be desired. For having one of the highest MP cameras on a phone, the quality is sub-par. If a great camera is something that you want, try a different phone. My friend has a Google Pixel 3, and it takes amazing pictures effortlessly.
Other than that, the phone met functionality expectations which is the only reason why it didn't get a 1. I'm mostly rating it low because this seller is BS, and I don't want them to lie anymore on their description and questions when they're asked which networks this phone is compatible with.

Crazy good deal for $400. This display on this phone is beautiful. I'm super happy with it and it's crazy how fast the prices on last year's flagship phones have dropped. Updates on this phone will be below average(Feb 2019 patch at the time of this review), but I knew that going into this purchase and felt that it was worth it to get such good hardware at a mid range price. This phone should get android 9 Pie, probably not Q though. I wish LG was better with the updates and patches but just about any Android phone is gonna be some type of compromise. Performance on this phone is top notch, it has everything you could want- IP68, wireless charging, USB 3.1 data transfer speeds, Snapdragon 845, 3120x1440p display, Dual cameras with video recording on the Ultra wide angle lens, UFS 2.1 flash storage, Super loud speaker, 32 bit quad DAC. If you are into photography then you should side-load the Google Camera app with Night Sight because then you can really maximize the hardwares ability to capture images. All and all, I think this is a solid choice for anyone who wants a solid phone that will last a couple of years but doesn't have 800-1000 to spend on an iPhone XS or Galaxy s10. And once again, this item is a NEW Unlocked LG G7 (G710ULM).
Works perfectly on AT&T, very snappy phone, extremely loud audio, would buy again !

I love the 2 full days I can go without a recharge and spending 3 to 4 hours a day using the phone. If you've got the money for this phone its a wise choice it uses both GSM and CDMA bands just depends on the sim card you put in it as Ive had both types of sim cards installed I would have preferred that the back came off or they would have sent the key to open the tray for replacing the sim card and the external storage for the price you pay it should be included but instead I had to order the sim card key from amazon too

Is this phone cheap? No. Is this phone overly expensive? Also no. It's got a great headphone jack with a custom quad DAC chip built into the phone co-developed between ESS and LG. It will drive your higher end headphones well. It has google assistant built in. It has a decent size battery and all the latest doodads to charge it including quick charge and QI wireless charging. The processor puts it on equal footing with the S9+. Also it has this nice new feature where you can use it to place telephone calls. Crazy what they can do with technology these days.

I've had this phone for close to 6 months now. It's still going strong.
I got the android 9 update, and the software works nicely.
Battery life is really good. I don't even charge it at night when I don't use it much during day. When in need, a quick 30min charge with the fast charger included is enough to get back over 50%.
The phone is very responsive, just like a $800 phone. The fingerprint reader integrated in the back is very convenient.
The audio is awesome. When you connect headphones to the jack, a dedicated DAC takes over, and you can hear the difference vs my previous phone. The integrated speakers are loud enough for calls and podcasts, but you'll still want to connect to a bluetooth speaker for better sound to enjoy music.
The camera is good in bright light and has a wide angle option. But is still slow to respond to trigger, and I'm not happy with low light results. I can't give up my DSLR yet!
Overall I highly recommend this phone. You are not giving up much under $400, compared with phones double the price.
