I bought this for the following to replace my old Sony XZ.
1. Radio -- yes, some of us listen to the radio, but it wasn't a major factor.
2. Audio jack -- bad experience with dongles. Bluetooth don't last if you're on the phone for hours for work. This was a key factor.
3. 2 year limited warranty. This kind of sweetened the deal.
Other reasons to like this:
1. Music. I heard about the audio feature and was majorly impressed compared to my Sony XZ which I replaced this with.
Some things to get used to:
1. Getting used to the new interface coming from a different brand. Not a major issue.
2. Slightly larger than I expected. Cannot simply use my thumb to do one finger typing as much anymore. Oh well.
Overall, I was deciding between the Samsung S9 and the LG G7 ThinQ. I first came across the LG G7 while browsing at Best Buy and noticed the LG G6 on display. After researching more online, I decided on the LG G7 and purchased it online. I haven't regretted this purchase yet!

I got this phone as a present and really love it. Was able to try this and some of it's competitors in a store to see how each felt in my hand, how easy was it to handle, how good was the display and I took photos of the some object (my husband) at the same distance with each one.
I take quite a few pictures so I was happy so the final determiner for me was the clarity of the pictures and quality of the color without using filters. Call quality is splendid. Display is so great I don't even have to use my reading glasses.
And the different features are very fun and easy to use.
Great processor as well.

Last year LG made a big deal about how they were going to update their phones in a timely manner. This could not be further from the truth. Here we are in Q2 of 2019 and this phone is still on Android 8 (not even 8.1).
Coming from a pure Android before that got updates within a few months, this is a huge disappointment. LG Android customizations are more annoying than useful and hardly outweigh the new features that Android 9 has. I would gladly go to a stock Android OS if it meant they could roll out an update in a timely manner.
LG spends all of their resources making new phones (who else has 2 "flagship" phones at the same time that are so similar it's difficult to tell them apart?) instead of updating the phones they have and wonders why their Mobile devision is failing.

I am no stranger to smart phones and have been both an Android and an Iphone user. I avoided Samsung because I felt they had become bloated and overpriced and I wanted a cheaper phone that shared many Samsung Specs. So I ended up with the LG G7 which turned out to be one of the most disappointing phones ever. Here were the dissapointments in order : 1) The battery life - drained VERY quickly. Even though it speed charges I don’t always have access or time. 2) The photo quality. Terribly disappointing and worse than my 7 year old Note 3 that I still own. Massively digressed here. Not only poor quality but photo does funky things like refusing to focus on close-ups and doc scans. 3) Fingerprint sensor failed. LG said to factory reset the phone which did not help. Now I cannot login to my phone or apps/accounts with fingerprint scan. 4) Phone became very sluggish, especially when unlocking, takes a few to start. 5) Phone does not have as good of reception on same service as prior phones. 6) The screen remains on the entire time on a call. Trying to turn it off in usual manner (power button press) disconnects the call. 7) The sim / micro sd card tray is too small and takes great effort to get either one in without them popping out again.
**** UPDATE **** Literally within a week of posting this review the phone completely quit working. Cannot hard reset, cannot do anything. I've contacted LG warranty since I bought this as a brand new phone, but unless you buy from Best Buy or other "authorized retailer" you are out of luck. Complete dud. See the photo, I literally get a question mark on the screen when trying to turn it on, and that is it. Nevermore LG, you have been screwing people since 2015 when your flagship phone, the G4, had bootloop issues forcing users to seek service centers so they can get their devices running again

I recently secured a new job and after accepting it, realized rather suddenly that I'm going to have to return my current Samsung S8+ and I'll need another device. I wasn't able to get into what I really wanted (the Note 9) but I did some research and decided to go with the G7. The name, 'ThinQ' is a bit of silly name if you ask me, but oh well. My last LG phone was the G3, which I genuinely liked. I wasn't eligible for the G4 upgrade, and when the G5 modular phone came out, I had made a firm decision not to get it at all (as did most of you). I went with the Galaxy S6+, then the S7 Edge, the S8+ and I was firmly entrenched within the Samsung eco-verse, and fully expected another one was in my future. But that was not to be.
As I mentioned, I did my research and decided to go with the G7. For my budget, it was not just the best phone option, but also, probably the best phone available for that price. It has the internals of the more expensive Samsung rivals, (except only 4gb RAM instead of 6 in the S9+). The screen is almost the exact same size and that within a smaller frame, not a bad trade-off if you ask me.
I was a bit disappointed that LG hadn't fallen in line and upgraded to an OLED screen like even apple has, but I must say, that whatever LG is doing, well keep doing it because the screen is genuinely fantastic. LCD or OLED, this screen is vivid, and amazing. It can get ridiculously bright which makes the screen easily readable in virtually any light. Honestly, I cannot see the difference between it and the Super AMOLED screen on my S8+ if I'm being honest. I almost decided not to go with the LG for the LCD screen alone, but I'm glad I chose to give it a shot anyway. LG hits a home run with the G7 screen. Stunning and beautiful. The one place where OLED beats the LG however is in the deep blacks and how easily it is to save battery life by switching to a screen with more solid blacks. Not an option here, but dang, this screen shouldn't stop you from considering getting the G7 like it did me initially.
The build is top notch...but that only means in order to support wireless charging, it will have to be a bit more vulnerable than phones with all metal backs. It's a trade-off, but worth it if you know the convenience of wireless charging, trust me. Solve this issue by getting a good case that allows for wireless charging and you'll be set.
An honest-to-goodness 3.5mm headphone jack? Right when many are getting rid of them...its a bold move but one I certainly appreciated. The Quad Dac audio player is, especially for a mobile phone, just plain amazing. You're going to hear better audio with this phone, especially with earbuds and headphones than you will with arguably any mobile device out there. I love mine. It's almost worth buying for this alone.
A lot has been made of the cameras, and I found them to be pretty dang good. I don't think you're going to find much to scream about, but in my opinion, I found them to be on par with my Samsung. I haven't experimented much with it yet, but I will and may do a quick update here before too long.
The boom speaker...hmmm. A bit more underwhelming than I expected, especially considering how much LG brags about it. While it certainly gets much louder than my S8+ and I truly appreciated that, is it loud enough that you'd consider using it to watch a movie? Uhhh, no. At least I sure wouldn't. Music sounds better, but just not anywhere as good as I expected considering what I read and saw for the G7 marketing.
USB-C charging, another welcome addition, along with fast charging and wireless charging, too. Once I got used to both of these features, I'm telling you it is quite difficult to go back to something that does not offer this as a standard feature.
The multiple ways to unlock the phone is pretty impressive. You have your standard fingerprint sensor, which is just about a perfect placement since that is where your finger rests naturally most of the time anyway and wasn't LG the first to employ this feature in the first place? You can opt for using a pattern or code or even facial recognition, which I found to be much better than my S8+ and along with that, much faster. It was so unreliable, that I turned it off entirely on the S8.
Gorilla Glass 5 on front and back (I read elsewhere that they used GG 4 on back and 3 on front, but I just confirmed at LG's own site, that was incorrect) help make this very vulnerable looking phone more protected than it looks...but with that said, I still recommend a good case and screen protector (I MUCH prefer glass over the older silicone ones). Regardless of how careful you may be, it isn't a question of if, but when you will accidentally drop it and then you'll find out just how accurate their claims are regarding how tough it may be. Why take that chance? Even if you are super careful, it may be someone else handling your device who drops it--the point is, do yourself a favor and take care of it.
Speed...while it wasn't a huge step up from what I noticed with my S8+, I DID notice how smooth it seemed to be and how much less LG's skin seemed intrusive than it did back when I had the G3. I think this is a move in the right direction. ANY time you can bring a device closer to stock android, is a better move. LG seems to always be in Samsung's shadow and therefore tries to take its own spin on things and the G7 is no exception. Samsung had some fantastic themes that were exclusive to their devices and I found out the other day, the G7 has some to choose from as well. Nowhere near as many, mind you, but some were actually pretty decent...but I'd sacrifice it all for stock android.
And finally...that notch. Ever since the iPhone X came out with that notch, it seemed that you either were okay with it, or you hated it. Not many in betweeners. Say what you want about it, but if you want more screen real estate, you have 2 options, either place the camera somewhere other than on the front of the screen (some have a novel, mechanical pop-up camera) or you place it on front and work around it somehow. LG embraced this and you have the option of getting rid of it, or keeping it. I find that for most things, it simply doesn't bother me, which I found to be a surprise considering before I got it, I really thought it would bug me silly. But nope. You may be different however, which is why the option to remove it entirely is a nice touch.
The dedicated Google Now button is an almost direct ripoff of Samsung's Bixby button...except that Google Now is actually useful unlike Bixby, which most users simply turn off. It can do almost anything Google can do--just a whole lot slower. Sure, it has a few features that Google Now and Siri cannot do, but they are so slow, you may as well just do it by hand yourself. The other issue is that like Bixby, this button activates Google and nothing else. You cannot remap it to open other things that may also be super convenient for you like say the camera, or the phone etc. LG, if you want to take a leap ahead of Samsung, you're going to need to have the courage to make the decisions that Samsung refuses to do. Just sayin'.
All in all, a very underrated phone that may be hampered a bit due to LG's inability to market their devices with any kind of genuine success...which is too bad. This phone is exceptional and the equal to almost any device out there today.

Purchased through Verizon not Amazon, but am very happy with this phone. It replaced my droid turbo 2. I did a lot of research first and am happy I did. It's quick, has a great quality screen, takes nice pics (even in low light), and is very customizable and user friendly. Glad it still has a headphone jack and SD slot. Battery life is not unbelievable, but it seems comparable with all the other major models out there now. Also, sound quality is a little disappointing - the loud end really loses quality and sounds tinny. But overall, I would recommend to a friend and would purchase again myself.

The phone I received is NOT compatible with Sprint or Verizon networks. LG distributes some factory unlocked phones directly and some through Brightpoint, and the ones that come from Brightpoint are only compatible with a select few carriers, which does not include Sprint or Verizon. On the box the model number is listed as LM-G710ULMBPTPL, this model uses different LTE and CDMA bands that do not work with most US carriers. LG really should list these models separately. I spent nearly two hours on the phone with Amazon, LG, and Sprint trying to get this phone to activate and it is not possible, because this phone is not compatible.

A 6000 mAh power bank battery is absolutely necessary if you are away from a power source for more than 4 hours. When I'm playing games, the battery rarely lasts over 4 hours. If you are playing or watching shows in bright daylight, the battery will be depleted within 2.5 hours.
Photos are above average with good low light performance and excellent daylight performance. Back-lit images are washed out and just terrible. Auto focus is weak, so you have to manually touch the screen before most shots.
That said, I love that I was able to buy a phone with a Snapdragon 845 processor and 4 Gigs of memory for under $400 (elsewhere)- those are flagship specs as of early 2019. The longer screen means you lose a lot of horizontal real estate compared to other 6 inch phones, but it helps you enjoy movies shot in 16:9 ratio. The screen on boosted mode is bright enough for direct daylight even with polarized sunglasses.
The waterproofing rating allows it to be taken on snorkeling trips as well as into the shower. I've never had a single program run slowly in the 6 months since I bought it. Passmark benchmarks put it at the top 90% of phones in the market. I would recommend this if you are on a budget, and don't mind 2X, or 3X a day recharging. Fortunately, as long as you have a 2 Amp or faster charger, this phone fully charges within 60 minutes. 1A charging ports require at least 3 hours.

got mine used, it didn't come with any accessories but I have found no blemishes... I can buy accessories xD
ANYWAY my biggest complaint is it's still on Android 8 Oreo! C'mon LG and this is on Google Fi it's fully endorsed by GOOGLE I did not expect that :/. Android 9 should come but Android 10 is out so... c'mon LG worst support EVER (for a flagship device). 16:9 videos UNDERSTANDABLY don't fill the 18:9 screen (I don't know what I was expecting...). The camera (though NOT something I know much about) is really not that great... word is due to software overhead (Android 9 where are you??)... but the one shot I took was SO blurry, if I really cared though I could find a better app to use and so on but default it SUCKS (I hear it gets pretty good though...). OK it MIGHT be a little unresponsive of a touchscreen too- I've noticed on my tappy tap tap game it sometimes takes 3 or 4 taps to find the 'hotspot'... I mean maybe it's me but... my history with LG is like this so... it could be the software? I will update when I mod the phone if it is actually a thing... also part is cuz I'm not used to such a small bezel like where does the screen end? so I could be touching the bezel.
That's a short set of negatives on a 300 dollar (400 new) phone though, pluses include WIDESCREEN camera- not that I care about that but it seems to be all the rage, a BOOMIN speaker (just 1 speaker mind you... but I can HEAR IT IN THE SHOWER without bringing it into the actual shower that is LOUD) that's basically a bluetooth speaker, quad dac that makes my $50 100 ohm Yamahas sound like $500 Bose (overpriced but hey! you get the idea- Bose headphones are better quality than their speakers though), super bright screen I can see outside and a great 5+ hour screen on time (basically all day battery).
So with it being SUPER affordable with plus specs AND Google certified (though slow updates :/ I believe they will come eventually) I count 3 negs (not counting the aspect ratio one... that's an android issue really) to 5 positives HIGHLY recomended!

Phone (or, its USB-C port, which is the same thing) died within 7 months. LG won't replace the faulty product, which means you have to be without a phone for 2+ weeks (they ship ground, no fancy air shipping for them).
The punchline? The replacement phone (a refurb) I bought to hold me over has a problematic USB-C port as well. That makes it 2 out of 2.

I needed an unlocked phone and had not a clue what to get. Spent a great deal of time reading reviews and comparing stats. Narrowed it down to 4 and went to see them locally where I could see them in person side by side. Took a photo of the same object and it made the choice easy. All things being equal, this phone had the better processor and quality of photographs. The display, it's so clear. Calls are perfections.

I have had this phone (bought unlocked online just like this one here) for over a year and I love it. I have no idea why it's got such a mediocre rating here. Sure, the camera quality is not as good as Samsung or iPhone, but the wide angle lens MORE THAN makes up for that! See attached!
The quad DAC was the main reason I switched from Samsung to LG and I'm not disappointed. It really does sound awesome when you plug in a nice pair of wired headphones! Note: you don't get the benefits of the quad DAC without a wired headset.
Claro Network? TF is that? This phone has not been unlocked for usage with Sprint network in the U.S. Be gone with you.

I love the IPS screen. It is very pleasing and easy on the eyes.
The phone is slightly narrow which is nice. Less wide makes it easier to use.
Headphone jack is nice to have.
Great phone. What else is there to say? And LG has excellent sound, even better than HTC in their golden age. Comes with a very good DAC.

I have now had two experiences with them that were both around their horrible design for SIM card handling. On the G6, they have such a flimsy SIM card tray that they routinely break and often that is inside the phone...damaging contacts as you try to pull the mangled tray out. Do a quick search and you will see how many vendors offer replacement trays, and how many users are screwed by the thing breaking inside the phone. That is then YOUR problem, because it is "physical damage", and is not covered by their warranty program. Add to that the repair policy of it taking 2 weeks to turn your repair around (so yu have no phone) and the result is:
I will NEVER buy another LG phone, and I strongly suggest you also avoid their products!!!!

Does not preform like a phone of this spec should. The battery life is absolutely abhorrent, the fingerprint sensor is slow and very inconsistent, and the software experience is very buggy. The camera app is constantly crashing. The normal camera has A very narrow field of view but can take good pictures. The wide angle camera is of horrible quality. The selfie camera is awful. Snapchat videos and pictures are laggy frame rate dropping messes. And trying to watch videos is a constant drag and buffer freezing disaster. And it's not internet related, I have other devices on the same source that play the same video flawlessly. Its just this phone. Its awful. No screen protector fits it right either. And the mono bottom firing speaker is trash! Phone calls are super quiet even on max volume. This phone is awful!

Received the phone unlocked and new as promised. However, there are still other issues:
You can't update the phone outside of AT&T network. Because this phone is still new in its box, its on an old android 8 version. If you want to update the phone, you need to connect to the ATT network with an ATT sim. LG and ATT have designed it this way. You won't be able to update it any other way, and the bootloader is locked. Supposedly it is possible to flash other firmwares onto the phone, but of course this isn't supported by LG.
To do this, I had to obtain a ATT sim from walmart ($10 at walmart, 5$ from ATT) and a prepaid card (you can use a $10 prepaid card, but I found out they allow you to activate a single-day plan for only $2)
That cost me $20, although it should be possible to do for $7. Either way, its stupid that I have to go through this just to update the phone. Shame on you ATT, and to LG for going along with it.
Anyways, about the phone itself:
This phone is at least 1 year old with a non-removable battery. After charging it a few times and measuring it with accubattery, the battery has lost 10% of its health, effectively making it a 3000mAh battery.
Aside from that, this is an amazing phone. Its easily one of the best values for the price. The OLED screen is beautiful, it makes me want to re-watch everything I've ever seen using this screen. It plays all of the games I used to play on my V20, but with higher settings and is very smooth.
The design is meh. I hate that every manufacturer feels the need to copy Apple's decisions. Nobody feels that they could stick to their guns or try to make a unique design. (Motorola's new flip-phone looks pretty neat though) I really with it was closer to the V20 in design, or some of the old HTC phones. But overall, the phone is really great.
The sad thing is, this is the best high-end value phone LG currently has. (The V20 and V30 are still good if you're fine with their age)
The V40? A new V40 (GSM version) costs over $600 (CDMA version is $330, if you're willing to switch), and is basically the same phone but with 3 cameras instead of 2.
The G7? An IPS screen and only 4GB RAM. For the same price, its just not worth it. Especially now that I've experienced the OLED screen, I can't go back. The difference between these two phones is ridiculous considering these phones released only one month apart from each other. The V35 is basically a really hasty correction to the G7 when LG realized they released a sub-par phone.
The G8? Hardware-wise, the G8 is a slight upgrade, with Snapdragon 855(vs.845), 128GB, and an extra camera. Its about $180 more than the V35 though. (Used ones are at $320-340, if you're willing to accept the risk then it might be worth it.) If only the V35 wasn't so tied to AT&T, I believe it would be much more popular as a $300 phone.

This phone is GSM unlocked. Worked with my T-Mobile sim just fine. No notches, nice light weight especially if you're worried about a case making it too heavy.Unfortunately it was stuck on Android 8.0 with November 2018 security patch. It should have updated to Android 9. Maybe if you try an AT&T sim card it'll go through the update. These days you can't underestimate security risks in phones.

I have complete removed and updated my review on this phone and updated my rating from four to five stars.
This phone is brand new. I was concerned because of the seller listing these phones under a dozen different seller names that are all the same company and many reviewers complaining that they received a used phone. (I suspect they unknowingly ordered a used/renewed phone or possibly inventory got mixed up when the seller shipped them to Amazon.) If you ordered new and got used just send it back for replacement. Mine was sealed in the ATT box and came with everything expected.
While waiting for my number to be ported to AT&T I hooked up to my wifi and that took no effort at all. I went through uninstalling or disabling apps and games I don’t want and customized the phones settings and home screen to my liking. I was prepared to restore my data from a backup on my SD card, but found that it was unnecessary. Instead, I installed AT&T Mobile Transfer on my old phone and using the Setup and Transfer app on the ThinQ I easily transferred all my data over to the new phone via wifi. Any apps I had installed were of course updated with google play. I immediately noticed that the phone was blazing fast compared to my old LG Stylo 2, but maybe that isn’t saying much. (I miss my stylus.) I haven’t put it through any real stress test yet, but I did fully charge the battery and then started streaming a movie. I kept checking the battery and it seemed fixed at 99%. I didn’t watch to long, but my old Stylo 2 drained like a bathtub when streaming a movie. Using LG Airdrive on the phone and LG Bridge on my laptop I could easily browse files on my phone and transfer things to and from the laptop such as photos, music and movies. Is there anything that isn’t easy with this phone?
Well, the bio metric sensor can exercise your patience. It doesn't seem to have to many issues reading finger prints - once it's learned them. Teaching it I found to be rather tedious. I probably saw 'The sensor needs to be cleaned' a thousand times. I cleaned the sensor. I scrubbed my hands. Eventually, I was able to get five fingers learned. Nice to have backups. The manual states there will be an issue if you have a scar. It's not kidding. I have a scar right down the center of the pad of my left index finger and the sensor had a heck of a time learning it. However, once it learned any of my prints, including the scarred finger, they all did unlock the phone, but not with consistency. Sometimes one touch and the phone is unlocked. Other times I touch each finger that the phone has learned and none of them unlock the phone so I have to go to the secondary method I chose. I'll work on it.
Wifi calling does work. I tested on my home internet which is pretty lousy and the call kept breaking up, but that's my internets issue not the phones. I see no reason to use wifi with my unlimited plan anyway. I guess if I'm in an area where there is no cell service it might come in handy, but odds are that if there is no cell service it is unlikely that any wifi will be nearby.
Hotspot worked like a charm as well. I hooked both my laptop and TV up with no issues. Download speed was only about 5Mb, but when my internet is down or we have a power outage it's better than nothing.
Once my phone number was ported over to ATT I made some calls. They hear me fine and I hear them fine.
The phone handled streaming from Amazon Prime with flying colors. I kept hearing about the great sound on this phone. I wasn't impressed, but who doesn't use buds when listening to music anyway.
This does come with Android 8. Repeated attempts to update to 9 failed. The phone tells me the software is up to date. Last updated says 'never updated'. ATT did release 9 for the V35 months ago and ATT is my provider/carrier. Not Cricket or any other MVNO. I seriously considered going to the ATT store to have the update manually done, but I live outside of town so I plan my trips to town when I have several reasons to go. I never got that far.
I had started my prepaid promotional plan with ATT and paid upfront for a year of service. Five days later ATT billed me a second time. I did call ATT and work out the issue, but something else happened at this point. I made my daily attempt to update my phones software and lo and behold it started updating. My phone came with V350AWM10w. The update skipped 12a and updated to 12e. I updated again and got 12j. The next update skipped 12k and updated to 20b. I now have Android 9! I do another update to 20c and one last update to V350AWM20d. That’s the most current software. I suspect I just had to wait for ATT to properly put my new phone in the system. When they did that they erroneously charged me again, but I fixed that. So apparently in order to get the updates you just need to be patient. Not my forte. I did notice that when the phone was sitting on my wireless charger during updates the phone got pretty warm. It did not get warm doing updates when not on the charger. I don't know why.
I mentioned LG Bridge earlier. Install on your PC. It works just fine and makes it extremely easy to move files to and from the phone. It supposedly can be used for software update by connecting your phone to your computer with a USB cable, but I tried during my marathon updating and it wouldn’t work so I just did all the updates from my phone. LG Bridge connects to your phone using your phones LG AirDrive too. Air Drive isn’t exactly an app. You find it in your settings under network. This gives you access to the files on your phone like songs and pictures which you can just grab and drop onto your PC. LG Bridge also connects to your V35 via USB cable to perform backups which will be kept on your PC of coourse.
I checked out my phone online and found that it was manufactured October 2018 and left the factory December 2018. It apparently sat on the shelf until I bought it which explains why it was so far behind in updates.
I have absolutely no complaint with this brand new phone. It’s clean. It’s fast. Everything works flawlessly, except maybe that bio metric reader when sticking your fingerprint on there, but I doubt that's something unique to this phone. It's just something I'll need to work on. I believe my issue is with my dry hands and fingers.
My only two issues were ATT issues. (Double billing and waiting for the software update to Android 9.) I thought this deal was to good to be true and I would have lots of problems and be dissatisfied with the phone, but it turned out to be a great deal on a great phone. I couldn’t have made a better decision making this purchase. I say you should take the plunge and purchase this phone because you will get a brand new phone that works great. It's being sold at a great price so you should get one before they're gone.

I'm NET10 user(SIM is compartable for AT&T) so, I have to set up APN for getting NET10 data service. It took for a while because I had to find out the correct one (NET10 doesn't provide it on their website anymore so, I had to Google it.lol). This brand-new phone works PERFECT for me. I loved my previous LG G5 but this one is way better. There is no problems, so far so good working. Worthy shopping!

I've seen many different reviews for this item but none state what company there device came from. Mine came from Wireless warehouse. The phone was new in a sealed box. The phone has worked flawlessly so far. The phone is much faster than my previous phone a Stylo 3. Apps open immediately moving between apps is fast with no delays. A pleasure to use. The screen is beautiful and bright. Battery life has been great. The camera takes nice pictures. I haven't used it a lot. I have a Nikon camera with a nice lens on it that I use for taking pictures. This an AT&T phone with included AT&T bloatware. There isn't a lot of it and the 64gb storage still leaves you with plenty of free storage. Some you can uninstall. The rest I just disabled or move to a folder.
I went to AT&T and bought a pay as you go number. I then upgraded to Android 9.0 no problems. Had to restart the phone about 10 times for all the updates. One thing I didn't like is that it wouldn't update over cellular data. It would only use WiFi. So I might not have had to get an AT&T number. the update went smooth with no problems. I bought the AT&T number because some people have said that you had to.
When that was finished I put my old sim in the phone and it came right up and worked fine. I'm with Walmart family mobile. I had called them and asked if it would work on the network. They said I would have to get a new sim from them. That is not true. Everything is working fine. The only thing that is not working is WiFi calling. Mobile hotspot is working great. Coverage is the same as the Stylo 3. I had to enter the apn codes. You can find them on the Walmart site. I haven't tried the wireless charging yet so I can't comment on that.
So I would say that I am very pleased with this purchase and would recommend this phone and seller without hesitation.

Original, ATT branded, unopened new device. Seller Wireless Tech. I already have ATT, so can't determine if truly unlocked, but for under $300, this phone is a smoker, must have performance. Put it this way, original price of this phone a little over year ago was $900!! Would I pay that? No. But at $300 dollars you are getting flagship device which can still compete with today's overpriced options. Get it.
Brand spanking new phone. Works great. Been using about a month now. Super happy with purchase.

I had been eyeing between this and the v40 ThinQ. The battery is slightly better than the v40 but the v40 is more powerful in terms of performance of running Apps, in my opinion. It's also REALLY BRIGHT at max brightness, compared to the v40. My eyes were just blinded by light.
I bought this phone last week and I'm only going to use it as a 2nd device for music or playing mobile games. Which so far, mobile games load up almost 50% faster on the v35 than the v40. However, there's a drop due to the graphics settings, depending on the App. I still need to wait on the case for the v35 because the phone is about 1/3 thinner than the v40. My other complaint on the v35 is the fact the fingerprint reader is also the power key. Which I feel is really impractical. It's like finding a house that's only held in the middle of the air by a single staircase. So I'd only use the Fingerprint Scanner as the Power Key.
Overall though, it's a pretty neat phone. But good lord, it's really sleek enough to slip off my hands if I'm not careful. A sturdy case is definitely recommended.

I have had the LG G5 for many years, but dropped it recently and broke the screen - so I thought I'd rather upgrade! My G5 was COMPLETELY virgin - no bloatware, just pristine Android phone, that I bought on Amazon for $250 several years ago. It was completely unlocked, and since I travel to Europe a LOT, I always used local EU SIMs and G5 always worked like a charm, including tethering - which I use a LOT to connect my laptop to my phone. So, the LG V35 ThinQ is an awesome phone - I loved it .... until, I started testing the functionality that I must have. It worked out of the box on my Cricket Wireless SIM, it also by default enabled wifi calling on Cricket Wireless, however it would not up allow me to even start tethering unless I have an ATT SIM. This was really shocking ... shame on ATT on blocking basic Andriod functionality by installing their ROM and blocking built-in Android features! So, sadly, I ended up returning the phone!
If someone's figured out how to get tethering working without ATT SIM card, please let me know. I don't mind blowing away all the bloatware from ATT just once and for all. However, I must have tethering working for the phone to be useful to me.
It's a shame that ATT is so cheap and ripping off customers .... otherwise, it's a great phone and I'd buy it again.

I was waiting for the delivery- it was personally handed to me on my porch - so no drop no issues on delivery with that. The item appeared as new - mfg box appeared sealed. It was only after discovering defects I noticed there was no mfg seal on screen or ports - AGAIN - it was advertised and sold as a NEW phone. I spent an entire day updating and calling LG etc - the external speaker never worked. It was deemed by LG to be a faulty or badly "renewed" phone. I wasted a vacation day trying to update the system and hoping it would work.t did not. I then had to explain my return to Amazon - I am a prime member who buys high end products regularly. My payment went through immediately - my refund not so much. All in all - this was NOT a good experience. I have reordered the phone and am prayerful my zero balance (no refund yet) wont become an even bigger issue and that the next "New" one I ordered wont be defective as well. #FeelingSuspectfulofNewBrandedItems and alo #SlowAmazon3rdpartrefund

Excellent. The real thing was delivered. I was disappointed by a earlier purchase of a phablet. I checked youtube and online videos of persons usage of the best phones and this one topped the list. I had an older LG for a long time and finally gave in to purchasing a new phone. The LG Thin Q is great! The order came shipped from the seller without any issues or problems. I love it. The apps and video clarity is most excellent. The battery will last over 16 hours of regular use and charges to full percent in about 20 minutes. The only thing I do not like about it is that pages of your last usage pop up in the background but if you want to use other tools or take notes while using the camera it shuts off.
Just as description. You will be satisfied

I dont know if anybody is even reading this but my experience with purchasing this phone from this seller was great even though this is an att n t phone it is unlocked and as you can see in the pics that the phone is on tmobiles network the phone did come with scratches on the screen but it didnt bother me i just put a screen protector on it and the phone does come with bloatware from the carrier and i got android 9 pie out of the box but im not too sure if this device will get android 10

Not a unlocked phone. Arrived in a timely manner, but when I tried to activate it on metropcs (T-Mobile) I discovered that it was not unlocked. AT&T would not unlock the phone, and I ended up returning the phone the day after it arrived.

WARNING THIS PHONE IS AN AT&T PHONE IT DOES NOT WORK WITH ANYTHING ELSE VERY GOOD BECAUSE IT MAY BE A RELEASED PHONE INSTEAD OF A UNLOCKED PHONE. LOTS OF BLOATWARE.
ALSO YOU CAN'T PUT IT IN A FACTORY MODE TO WIPE THE CASH AND DO OTHER TESTS ON THE PHONE. KINDA DISAPPOINTED THAT IT DIDN'T SAY THAT👎
Fantastic cell phone, very user-friendly, The delivery was on time, well packaged.
Stopped working within 2 days, contacted seller and Never heard back. Never buying from them again.
Excellent phone for the price. I would recommend this to anyone upgrading from an older phone like the galaxy s7 that does not want to spend $700 to $1000 for a flagship phone.

Why is it so hard to find phones without bloatware you cant delete. ATT's crap is all over this phone.
V35 is a great phone however and glad I got one.
I have been using it for two months , it hasn't crashed and it's good overall. The camera is a little slow to response but the photo quality is great .
Its not unlocked .. works only with with AT&T .. does not work with any other carriers.
The product is very good

First a warning, I bought this phone unlocked because although it's an AT&T phone, our account is T-mobile. It does work, but because the firmware is with another carrier, it doesn't work as as seamlessly as a T-Mobile phone would. That said, this is a very nice phone. It's fast, lightweight and attractive. All in all a great value, despite some minor limitations.

I've had the phone for over a month and a half now and I really do like it. I use to have lg Optimus g pro for 7 years and I really loved that phone too. Its similar in ways but this phone is better and im glad I did my research
$300, Great price for a high end phone.
Great phone for the price! Good camera. Lots of storage. Couldn't ask for more for the money paid.

for the price you really cannot beat this phone. It competes with phones twice the price. Mine came brand new. Battery life is excellent. Nicest phone I have owned to date and I used to be a Samsung fan...just no longer see the reason to pay more.

Fast battery replacement.
He is a responsible seller
Not new as adverised. Box has older sticker covered saying it is gray but i ordered black.
Only a charger was included in the puchased item? Where are the earphone and the case? These are among the items included when I buy a celphone in the Philippines, like Sony, Oppo and Vivo.
Nice phone. Fast. As discribed. Works well.
Had a bit of trouble getting the phone unlocked with att, but once I got the phone working on my carrier it met my expectations, great phone with a fantastic camera
Great phone. Definitely worth the money. Fast processor. Nice screen. Would recommend.
Phone works great! There was a small chip on the back of the phone. LG headphone did not come with this phone.
I like it much better than the LG K7 I had previously.
Great phone. Great screen quality and cameras are really cool. A lot of good features. The price also great.
Phone works great but a few functions that are lacking.
I love it. its very nice and great working. thanks

Excelente

Got this to replace a Pixel 2. Much smoother, faster, a bigger screen yet is light weight. LG's features and many settings are nice to have. I have had it 4 months as my daily phone without any problems. Sound system is great. I registered it on the LG site and bingo, a 2 year warranty. Can't beat that.
Update: Its been 9 months and the phone still works great with no problems. I have a couple of cases for it but I like using it without one.
LG products are the worst on the market..both the stylo 4 and styko 5 I owned failed within weeks..there must be sone systemic issues with their manufacturing process..

For the price, this phone is phenomenal. I received my device brand new in box, with all original components in tact and new as well. Yes, this is an unlocked AT&T device, so there will be an AT&T logo on startup and a couple carrier specific apps, most of which can be disabled and hidden through app settings. However, the phone is certainly unlocked and works great with T-Mobile for me.
Camera: The camera is probably the best I've ever personally seen on a smartphone that takes incredible shots with little effort. Videos are gorgeous and smooth thanks to the excellent hardware and onboard optical image stabilization. There are plenty of features to play with if you're into that, but the phone can point and shoot just as easily. Pictures are crisp and contain a lot of detail and the image processing does a great job of not blowing out images. Exposure is good and low light shots are very good. The pro video mode is great for creatung some very professional looking videos with ease, and the phone even has adaptive microphones for changing soundscapes from concerts to quiet nature scenes. Laser autofocus is fast and efficient. Honestly could not ask for a better camera at this price.
Battery: Easy win here. With heavy use on wifi, I average between 6-7 hours of screen on time. Even if you are a power user, you should have no issue getting through the day on the 3300 mAh battery. Even if you do manage to burn through that much battery, the included quick charger will easily get you 50 percent battery in 35ish minutes in my experience. Wireless charging is also here which is a great convenient option.
Display: The display is a 2k AMOLED panel provided by Samung (To the best of my knowledge). The display is sharp and color reproduction is awesome. You can adjust the resolution from 760p to 1080p to the max of 1440p. The screen is very bright and easily readable outdoors in direct sunlight. Great display.
Build quality: Outstanding. Glass front and back with aluminum sides. Everything is spot on here. No large gaps or out of place pieces. Beautiful device all around. Buttons are clicky and tactile. The fingerprint reader is very fast and extremely accurate and is also the power button which is essentially LG's signature design feature and it works well.
Overall: Unbeatable value considering this phone was over $700 USD at launch. I would venture to say it's definitely worth more than what you'll pay here. Highly recommend this device.

I've been using this LG a little more than a month now and I'd be hard pressed to find anything to complain about. I was a Samsung user for years and finally decided that they weren't worth the hefty price tag and took a chance on this. I absolutely LOVE it. I will say I disabled Alexa - but, that's only because we have multiple Echo devices in our house and the LG wanted to respond to inquiries as well. I also have the Echo Auto and there seemed to be a conflict with both active at the same time.
IMHO, this is an incredible device - battery life is outstanding, it's loaded with features you won't likely find on your Samsung or iphone. I found a side by side comparison online between the LG V35 ThinQ and the iphone 10 - the LG beat it hands down.
LOVE this device!

The screen and speed are important .. .hence the 4 stars. But the other stuff it boasts like fast charging and battery life? Well mine is either defective or they are embellishing those features. It is taking FOREVER to charge it and was using it (ok it was on full brightness but come on) for an hour and burned through 28% of the battery life! That just seems wrong! Anyway, maybe it needs to warm up. Still a zippy phone with a crisp, beautiful screen ... I think I'll keep it ... for now. Oh yeah, lacking features like gestures and such. Unimpressive set of tools. Oh well.
And an update: If you rely on vibration for text notifications, don't get this phone. The vibration can be strong, but for text I could not figure out a way to adjust it ... It is just too short and light of a burst. If someone can figure this out, please comment on this review and let me know. It's killing me that this is such a lame part of this phone as my phone is almost always set to vibrate because of where I work.

I had an LG V20 for four years. Loved it. Thought I'd stick with LG. The screen color is dull. Put the same pic as my wallpaper on this phone and it was washed out. Not as bright as a Samsung 8 or my other LG. I found I kept missing calls. The phone rang but I didn't hear or catch it but the swipe down notifications did not say missed call nor did the icon have a red number by it to tell me how many calls I missed. I had to go to the call log to see that. I missed several important calls! The battery life is just okay. Better than my V20 but way less than a Samsung. I bought a Samsung 8 and used it for two weeks. I wanted to go back to the double tap to wake up. Called customer service for help with the call notication and they did could not help the notification problem and suggested a factory reset. I said nope, I'll just return it to Amazon!

Absolutely fantastic phone! ... especially for under $300. I’ve seen some reports of problems with the fingerprint sensor, mine took several samples of my fingerprint to account for the print not always being perfectly centered. It always recognizes my fingerprint very quickly. Camera seems pretty good but I wouldn’t use a phone for any important pictures. I’ve seen reports of it not updating to Android 9, mine updated to 9 on the 3rd update attempt, I assume after some security updates. Battery life is a day with a good bit of use, 2 with moderate use, 3 with light use (I'm on 3 days with light to very light use at 65% battery). Processor is very fast. Has a 2 year warranty with LG if registered. I can’t imagine anyone having a complaint about this phone if they have the same one that I have.

The phone was functioning perfectly but it broke after a little over a month having it. The screen went completely black, I could still hear the noises it makes when locking and unlocking, but no calls and messages would go through.
I contacted the seller and they said I couldn't return it because I've had it for over 30 days, which is what Amazon Terms say too. But I think is quite ridiculous to have this kind of terms for electronics. I say, give it at least 90 days.
I was able to get 80% of my money back after complaining and calling Amazon SEVERAL times.
I ended up going to ATT and buying it there. Because I really liked the phone, the problem is that these phones are refurbished (another reason to give 90 days instead of 30)

I have been a smartphone user since their inception and the LG G vista 2, while not the latest and greatest, is very much worth the money. The Samsung note5, the only worthy competitor, is better but 2.5xs the price and the better features (pressure sensitive stylus etc..) are not needed for my use. I have found the phone fast and 'snappy' and have had no issues with email, text or any android function. I suspect that the upcoming lg stylus 3 will be better, but again only marginally. The G vista 2's call quality, browsing, streaming, emailing are all quite good. If you need the latest and greatest your still waiting for the note 8 or stylus3, but in either case this will do handsomely until one is ready to fork over $600+ for that nicety.

This phone has great specs but is very clunky and hard to use on the go.
The good:
You probably already seen how amazing this phone is on YouTube or other reviews, so im going straight to the point.
The bad:
- My number one complaint is the fingerprint reader. Its slow compared to my old phone (pixel 2xl) and it works like 50% of the time. Even after programming fingerprints multiple times its vey frustrating.
- requires a special addaptor tip to charge the phone when using the dual screen case. (Each tip is 7.99 + shipping from lg)
- said special adaptor tip doesn't work 100% with Android auto. Connection drops every two minutes or "no response" message pops up on the stereo
- all glass construction makes it extremely slippery if not using a case or the dual screen case (this is my first all glass phone, maybe this is normal or expected)
- Always on display is limited on info displayed and customisation options (it can display pictures, some notifications and clock.)
- selfie camera its not a true 32mp it downsizes files to 8mp
-dual screen turns off if battery is below 15% even if its plugged to the charger. Must wait for 16% battery charge
-its running android 9, who knows when the android 10 update is coming out. In the mean time android 11 beta is already out for some phones.
-Using the dual screen eats up the battery
- Display behind the dual screen has the resolution of a calculator and only has space for 3 notification icons
All in all is a good phone with good specs but in practice its really cluncky and akward to use. Would not recomend. Save your money.

I really enjoy this phone. To start off with, I'm not an android officiando but I love the dual screen feature of this phone. It is so mucb better than split screen to operate mutiple apps at once. I've had moments where I'm thinking "Ok. I need to get off this app to get on this one." only to realize "Oh yeah! I can use the other screen!" The first did have a buv which caused it to feeeze on occasion, but it got promptly replaced and haven't had any issues since. I appreciate LG and their willingness to not necessarily follow the trend of the bigger name phone developers.

I wanted to love this device. It seemed so unique, standing out against a sea of slab-style phones. Two screens won me over immediately. However, in person this phone did not impress me. The second screen is interesting, but I found myself with the second screen just sitting there waiting to be used most of the time. I liked being able to fold away the dual screen when not in use, however this just feels like admitting defeat; you spent money on the second screen, so tucking it away seems like a waste, so then you feel obligated to find used for it. I'd love to be able to open links from the main screen (facebook, email) on the dual screen, however this was not possible. I liked how texting and Facebook messenger would put your keyboard on one screen and the conversation on the other. This was one of the main reasons I bought the phone. However typing on it had less charm than I had anticipated. It doesn't match up to tactile qwerty keyboards of yesteryear and the keys, even when ergonomically split out wide closer to your thumbs, still felt like a chore. While gaming on this phone could be fun, battery dwindles quickly when both screens are in use so I'd have a charger handy. I like the dedicated google assistant button and both screens looked great. As many reviews have said before, this was an interesting idea that falls just short of being a GREAT purchase; just enough off the mark that I'll be switching back to a boring old slab until something else interesting comes along.

A pseudo-foldable that doesn't cost $2,000 and is still water- and dust-resistant. I call that a win. It's a different use model than the Samsung Galaxy Fold though. The Samsung is intended to give you a single double-size screen, whereas the LG G8X gives you "dual monitors" for running separate apps, i.e. multitasking. There is an app that allows you to run any other app across both screens, but I find that I don't use that nearly as much as just running separate apps on the two screens.
My niggles:
1. The front of the dual screen case is a mirrored fingerprint magnet nightmare... what were they thinking???
2. The notification screen is only minimally useful; a larger color screen would be more useful, but they presumably did this to hold down cost and battery life impact.
3. The little white button slide-out thingy that you have to press in order to turn on the dual screen after inserting the phone in the case is annoying AF. It's too tiny to reliably press on, and after you've enabled the dual screen, it just sticks around to interfere with any apps you are running on the main screen. Would be infinitely more useful if it were also available as a home screen icon/widget.
My hope is that since the dual screen case is technically an accessory, that LG or third parties will come out with a Gen 2, or other variants of the case that expand and refine its functionality... that G8X owners can buy separately rather than having to wait and re-buy the next generation of phone.

Awesome phone for multitasking! Can do multiple functions at the same time with two screens. Everything about this phone is well put together. I just took my Sim card from old phone and popped it in. Within 5 mins I was up and running.

It is a good phone so far. There are small differences from a Samsung, so I'm still adjusting. I greatly enjoy the second screen. I can look up a recipe on one screen, while watching a video of someone making the recipe on the other.

The dual screen is great for multi-tasking. It is, however, limited in what it can do. For example... You can't watch Netflix full screen. But you can watch it on one screen and do something on the other. LG is quality, as usual. It's a little on the heavy side. But you can take the phone out... Separate from the dual screen case.

This phone has been heaven sent. Let's address the elephant in this phone not a foldable screen. It has two screens. So yes by know means a Samsung fold. So here is where this gets interesting. I have the Samsung Galaxy Fold but I use my Lg Dual Screen a lot more and prefer my LG a lot more for a few reasons.
1. The Price $700 vs $2100
2. The build quality is much better than the fold.
3. Mult tasking is way easier with the split screen.
4. It handles everything I throw at it and never boggles down.
I would go out on a limb and recommend this phone and yes I know it's a LG phone but my honest opinion the best value and superior build quality and price point makes this the besphonce choice available today. So if you are in the market for an amazing phone and it having to burn a hold in your pocket I highly recommend that you give this phone a try. Take the leap like I did.

Love it, still learning about phone.. it's easy to work. Still haven't used Bixby...I prefer Google typing when I talk to type messages. Battery life is great..the finger print sensor is on front of phone and it took a few tries for me to have my fingers recognized, I had to keep adding fingerprints to the memory. Also I did get the unlocked version and all I had to do was take the phone to sprint to let them activate it for free, they provided me with sim cards that I did have to buy for a small fee. Also I would be careful when buying screen protectors, some of them cover the sensor and are too thick so it won't recognize your fingerprint. I have been getting phone updates and everything is working great. The phone came with a charger and ear buds. I would recommend!

I bought this phone to gift for someone and after I recieved it. It doesn't come with a factory seal. It just have a single tape holding the box together. On the in side the box the phone have a minor scratch on the screen and the phone's battery is not 100% seem like it been use and reset. It seem like I'm a bit picky but, I spends almost 1,000 for this to be a gift for someone. i should get some thing new, not something used and return. Called the customer service and the only thing they could do is, just to return it. I will buy another one and finger cross that I get a brand new factory seal box.

This phone is amazing with awesome battery life, good sounding speakers especially when Dolby atoms is turned on. I get the best graphics which shows up alot in pubg gameplay. I reccomend this purchase. No problems whatsoever although I will say the fingerprint scanner took a while to get used to.
Excellent smartphone, great photos, top quality.

Samsung's customer support is the absolute worst. Should you need to send your device in for repairs like I did, good luck on waiting. I was initially told it could take up to seven business days from the time the tablet was received at Samsung's repair facility. On the sixth business day after my device was received at their repair facility I received an email notifying me my device was received and it could take up to seven business days to repair. Then I made multiple calls to Samsung's customer service due to the conflicting information and received more conflicting information from the representatives with alot of apologies. Some reps told me they would resolve the issue and get back with me and I never heard anything back; others told me I received the wrong information from Samsung and other representatives. Each call with customer support involved the representative trying to call the repair facility, telling me they could never get in contact with the repair facility although they would leave a voicemail (as if this would provide some level of comfort). Needless to say, I am still in limbo without my device and weeks have gone by. I would strongly urge/recommend purchasing a device from Apple or some other reputable company due to the ordeal I have had to go through with Samsung's customer support. - A Very Dissatisfied Customer

it's terrible. every time I have to try 3-4 times to unlock.
samsung always makes such stupid inventions, such as screen finger print reader, curved screen etc.
